06:28 • 9 days ago

Verida

Polygon ID and Verida Make Zero-Knowledge Credentials Accessible to All

Verida launches the first mobile crypto wallet supporting zero knowledge credentials issued through Polygon ID. Millions of Polygon users now have access to an all-in-one mobile wallet to manage their digital identity, zero-knowledge credentials and crypto. This integration paves the way for Verida to become the self-sovereign identity and personal data layer for web3. Assertin
Verida launches the first mobile crypto wallet supporting zero knowledge credentials issued through Polygon ID. Millions of Polygon users now have access to an all-in-one mobile wallet to manage their digital identity, zero-knowledge credentials and crypto. This integration paves the way for Verida to become the self-sovereign identity and personal data layer for web3.

Asserting personal privacy online has become a necessary defense measure. A functioning society requires both freedom of expression and proof of identity, without exposing an individual‚Äôs private information.

Verida has integrated Polygon ID wallet SDKs to become the first consumer-ready mobile crypto wallet to support Polygon ID zero-knowledge (ZK) credentials.

Polygon ID is a set of identity infrastructure that gives developers the power to build secure and trusted relationships between users and apps, following the principles of self-sovereign identity (SSI) and supported by privacy features.

The Verida Wallet is a self-custody web3 mobile wallet where users can manage their self-sovereign decentralized identities and encrypted personal data all secured by the Verida Network.

The Verida Wallet is the first mobile crypto wallet to support Polygon ID ZK credentials that allow individuals to prove only the necessary information required for a transaction (ie: age over 21) without exposing any of their private information (ie: their date of birth).

In a single mobile application, the Verida Wallet enables an individual to manage their crypto, decentralized identity, zero-knowledge credentials and private data with a single private key.

Zero knowledge credentials ecosystem

Web3 platforms such as dApps, DeFi, GameFi, DAOs etc. can allow individuals to utilize their Polygon ID verifiable credentials to prove their access rights, in a zero-knowledge way, all through the Verida Wallet.

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs never been a more pressing time for this technology,‚Äù said Verida CEO and Co-Founder, Chris Were. ‚ÄúIndividuals, not companies, need to be in control of their personal data and online identities. We need to be able to verify information in a streamlined way and protect against impersonators, without revealing sensitive personal information.‚Äù

The Verida-Polygon ID integration is expected to unlock a new class of decentralized applications where personal data, reputation and real-world identity can be used privately and securely.

‚ÄúPolygon ID envisions a marketplace for credentials where it is easier to create trusted relationships between users and applications. Verida‚Äôs seamless user experience is essential to create self-sovereign trusted identities and we are very excited to have them in our ecosystem‚Äù said Sebastian Rodriguez, VP of Product at Polygon ID. ‚ÄúTogether, we are shaping the future of trusted identities and fostering a more secure digital landscape for everyone.‚Äù
Verida Wallet Features Feature-Rich Wallet for User Data Control

The Verida Wallet offers a comprehensive set of features, including:

Identity Management: Create decentralized identities, manage your private keys and take control of your digital world. User Data Control: Take ownership of your web2 data, store encrypted in a secure data vault. Control access to your data and provide permission to web3 applications. Inbox: Encrypted messaging between decentralized identities. Approve data requests, accept incoming data and receive notifications from your favorite web3 applications. Profiles: Manage public profiles for your decentralized identities that showcase your crypto wallets, NFTs and links to your verified web2 accounts. Take ownership of your web2 data, store encrypted in a secure data vault. Single Sign-On: QR code authentication for a seamless user experience. Simple authentication and anti-phishing architecture provides applications with secure access to your blockchain wallet and encrypted data. Tokens and Transactions: A multi-chain wallet with NFTs and SBT badges. Perform transactions and manage crypto on multiple blockchains. Credentials: Receive, store and share verifiable credentials across multiple identity networks. Bridge your credentials to applications and blockchains.

Polygon ID zero-knowledge credentials are secured by the Verida Network, the first self-sovereign data network developed for Web3. Credentials are encrypted on the user‚Äôs device and stored on region aware storage nodes that can only be accessed (or permanently deleted) via the user‚Äôs private key.

As the first mobile wallet to support zero knowledge credentials, the Verida Wallet unlocks an incredibly powerful interface for the next generation of Web3 users and applications.

Solving identity verification problems

The possible future use cases of the Verida-Polygon ID collaboration are exciting.

Sybil resistance: Projects can ensure uniqueness of users for airdrops, token launch initiatives, and GameFi projects.

Community role based access: Users can connect their Github via the Verida Wallet, prove they made a commit on the source code of an application, and automatically receive project tokens or stablecoins. Users can link up their Discord and prove they have answered five questions in the last month in the ‚ÄúQ&A‚Äù Discord channel to receive a ‚ÄúContributor‚Äù NFT.

Proof of reputation: Users can connect their LinkedIn and prove they worked at Google for two years and gain access to a private ‚Äúex-Googlers‚Äù chat room. Users can link their Twitter account and verify they signed up in the first year of Twitter to gain immediate access to a new decentralized social media platform.

Regulatory compliant DeFi: Users can complete a KYC process and show they have a valid, up-to-date KYC credential to access a DeFi protocol with lower fees and greater liquidity.

Proof of real-world assets: Users can connect their bank account and digital statements to receive a credential verifying their monthly income to access an undercollateralized DeFi loan. Similarly, they can take a photo of their car with their current registration certificate to prove ownership of a vehicle. They can submit this proof to a smart contract to access decentralized car insurance or obtain an insurance payout by submitting a verified police report that proves the car was stolen.

Zero Knowledge credentials powered by Polygon ID and the Verida Wallet How issuing credentials works

An individual authenticates with an Issuer of credentials and submits required documentation to receive reusable & rich verifiable credentials which saves to their Verida wallet in a self sovereign environment. This enables them to visit websites, use QR codes, and generate zero-knowledge proofs to verify credentials. The same verification capabilities can also be made available to smart contracts.

Credentials are sent directly from the issuer, using an encrypted connection between the web browser and Verida Wallet, then stored on our self-sovereign data network. This provides secure, encrypted decentralized storage for this highly sensitive information.

Just like any other wallet, a user‚Äôs private keys encrypt and authenticate access for complete ownership over their credentials. An individual can use their private key to securely access their Polygon ID credentials and data on other devices and applications or choose to permanently delete.

When a user receives a proof request from a Verifier to verify itself against a set of checkpoints or access controls, a zero-knowledge proof is generated locally within Verida wallet and gets submitted to the Verifier in a privacy preserving manner. This integration gets us one step closer to a decentralized world where individuals don‚Äôt have to sacrifice their privacy to enjoy personalized online experiences.

Download the Verida Wallet for iOS or Android at verida.io.

About Verida

The Verida Wallet is a self-custody Web mobile wallet. It‚Äôs more than just crypto, it‚Äôs a gateway to a new world of decentralized identity. Users can manage their identity, sign into apps, manage their personal data, their credentials, receive messages and manage crypto. The wallet connects users to the self-sovereign Verida Network, the most secure, encrypted decentralized storage solution for web3. This ensures all user data and credentials are secured by a user‚Äôs private key.

About Polygon ID

Polygon ID is a set of identity infrastructure that gives developers the power to build secure and trusted relationships between users and apps, following the principles of self-sovereign identity (SSI) and supported by privacy features.

Polygon ID enables trust issuers to connect with trust verifiers via verifiable credentials and SDKs created for each member of the SSI ecosystem. Individuals receive and store verifiable credentials in a personal wallet, and use zero-knowledge (ZK) proofs to privately verify the statements made about them. This enables anyone to securely interact with both off-chain applications as well as smart contracts without necessarily revealing personal information.

Polygon ID and Verida Make Zero-Knowledge Credentials Accessible to All was originally published in Verida on Medium, where people are continuing the conversation by highlighting and responding to this story.

Tether Reports Record Surplus Reserves

USDT Supply Has Increased By Over $20B In 2023
USDT Supply Has Increased By Over $20B In 2023
04:45 • 9 days ago

Brave Browser

Forgetful Browsing

Forgetful Browsing is similar to, but more powerful and protective than, popular browsing extensions and private browsing modes. It's another example of Brave offering the most powerful privacy features of any popular browser.

This is the 25th post in an ongoing, series describing new privacy features in Brave browsers. This post describes work done by Staff Engineer Aleksey Khoroshilov and was written by VP of Privacy Engineering Peter Snyder.

Most Web browsers are finally getting serious about limiting third-party tracking on the Web and‚Äîwhile no browser is as aggressive as Brave‚Äîthird-party trackers are taking notice of the trend. In response, third-parties are increasingly relying on first-party storage to continue tracking users. Forgetful Browsing is the first in a series of upcoming tools Brave has planned to continue protecting Brave users and address first-party reidentification.

Starting with desktop version 1.53, and Android version 1.54 1, Brave browsers will include a new feature called ‚ÄúForgetful Browsing,‚Äù which allows users to always clear cookies and other storage when the site is closed. Forgetful Browsing can help you:

Be automatically logged out of a site when it‚Äôs closed Avoid being rate limited by a site (e.g., ‚Äúyou have X remaining articles to view‚Äù) Generally prevent sites from reidentifying you across visits

Forgetful Browsing is similar to, but more powerful and protective than, popular browsing extensions and private browsing modes. It‚Äôs another example of Brave offering the most powerful privacy features of any popular browser.

The Web has the wrong defaults for privacy

Many privacy problems on the Web have a common root cause: by default, browsers let sites reidentify users indefinitely, but users only benefit from reidentification on a fraction of sites they visit.

In some cases, it‚Äôs very useful for a site to remember you (e.g. so you don‚Äôt have to log back into your email every day, or so you can easily use a social media account). But such sites are the exception, not the rule. Most often, you won‚Äôt benefit from being remembered by every news site you read an article on, or every shopping site you briefly browsed, or every image hosting site that showed you a cute cat picture.

In this way, all Web browsers get the defaults backwards: they assume you want to be identifiable by every site you visit. And this causes both annoyance (e.g. rate limiting or paywalls) and privacy harm (e.g. being profiled by untrustworthy sites). This problem is called ‚Äúunwanted first-party reidentification.‚Äù

The Forgetful Browsing feature‚Äîthe next step in Brave‚Äôs ongoing project to improve how browsers manage first-party storage‚Äîaddresses the reidentification problem head-on.

Browsers lack good protections against unwanted first-party reidentification

Browsers are getting better at protecting users against third-party tracking, but generally do a poor job of protecting against unwanted first-party identification. Brave already provides best-in-class protections against third-party tracking; Forgetful Browsing is one of several upcoming features in Brave that will provide similarly robust protections against first-party tracking.

Browsers provide some tools to help users prevent unwanted first-party reidentification, but these tools are clumsy, inconvenient, and scoped either too broadly or too narrowly, all of which invite unwanted‚Äìand irreversible‚Äìreidentification.

Consider this scenario: Khen has two email accounts, dolphinfan4ever@example.com and serious.guy@example.com, both of which Khen accesses through his Web browser. Khen doesn‚Äôt want the email provider to know both accounts are owned by the same person. Unfortunately, Web browsers make this kind of privacy very difficult.

This is because of how browsers manage first-party storage. Browsers prevent sites from reading another site‚Äôs cookies (e.g. yahoo.com can‚Äôt read your login cookies for outlook.com), but browsers generally don‚Äôt restrict how the same site can read cookies across visits (if you visited chicagotribune.com yesterday, the site can re-read the same cookies next time you visit). Even when you tell a site to log you out, it can‚Äôt easily clear some kinds of first-party storage 2. This gives even well meaning sites the ability to reidentify users across visits. Worse, browsers provide few protections against sites that intentionally aim to re-identify you across logins (as in Khen‚Äôs situation in the previous paragraph).

Browsers provide some tools you can use to be certain there are no identifying values persisting across site visits. Unfortunately, these tools are difficult to use and/or require user perfection; in many cases a single error can allow a tracker to permanently, irreversibly link to different accounts together.

Private browsing modes: Allow users to visit a site with a clean storage area, but require perfection to prevent unwanted first-party reidentification. If Khen (from the previous example) forgets to use a private window just once, and mistakenly logs into his second email account in a normal window, the email provider will be able to link the two email accounts, indefinitely and irreversibly.

Browser extensions: Can clear first-party storage whenever a user closes a site, but extensions are limited in their ability to clear cached values, or values in nested documents.

Clear all storage: Most browsers contain a feature like this, which clears first-party storage for all sites when closing the browser. However, this feature is, for most users, very inconvenient, since it will log a user out of all their sites, even those the user trusts and wants to stay authenticated with. The feature also does not provide much help for people who tend to leave their browser open for long periods of time. This feature is a sledgehammer when what‚Äôs needed is a scalpel.

Advanced site controls: Some browsers include this feature, which advanced users can use to manually clear, or otherwise micro-manage first-party storage for sites. These features are useful, but can be (depending on the browser) difficult to discover, need perfect use to prevent identification, or otherwise can be unsuitable for non-advanced users.

Forgetful Browsing prevents unwanted first-party reidentification

Forgetful Browsing, by contrast, allows Brave users to easily prevent unwanted first-party reidentification, in a way that‚Äôs convenient and does not require constant vigilance to get right. Using Brave Shields, users can indicate that they want to be forgotten when a site is closed. When this option is set, Brave will clear first-party storage for the site a few seconds after there are no more open tabs for the site. Forgetful Browsing clears both explicitly stored values (e.g. cookies, localStorage, or indexedDB) and indirectly stored values (e.g. HTTP cache or DNS cache).

Users can enable Forgetful Browsing in one of two ways.

Set Forgetful Browsing for a single site

Users can indicate that a specific site should be forgotten when it‚Äôs closed. To do so:

Navigate to the site. Click the shields icon in the URL bar. Click Advanced controls. Click Forget me when I close this site. Set Forgetful Browsing as a global default

Users can also make Forgetful Browsing the default setting for all sites. To do so:

Visit brave://settings/shields from the Brave browser. Click Forget me when I close a site.

Note that users can set this as the global default, and then use the steps outlined above (in the ‚ÄúSet Forgetful Browsing for a single site‚Äù section of this post) to create exceptions (i.e. to indicate that particular sites should not be forgotten). This allows you to configure Brave to clear storage everytime a site is closed except for your email site, a social media site you log into often, etc.

Forgetful Browsing applies to entire sites, not domains

Forgetful Browsing differs from other settings in Brave Shields in its scope. Most settings in Brave Shields are set per domain; Forgetful Browsing, meanwhile, is set per site. For example, you can configure first.site.example to use aggressive fingerprinting protections and second.site.example to use standard fingerprinting protections, but all subdomains on site.example will share the same Forgetful Browsing setting. This is necessary to align the Forgetful Browsing setting with how Brave (and most other browsers) enforce storage boundaries.

More coming to prevent unwanted first-party reidentification

Forgetful Browsing is one of several existing ways Brave protects against unwanted first-party reidentification on the Web. Brave‚Äôs Unlinkable Bouncing feature automatically clears first-party storage whenever the browser is bounced through known tracking domains. And Brave‚Äôs CNAME uncloaking feature allows Brave to block trackers even when they try to look like first-party resources. Brave also limits the lifetime of cookies set in JavaScript to seven days to prevent some forms of first-party tracking.

Forgetful Browsing is the first of several upcoming features related to further managing and improving privacy around first-party storage on the Web. Together, these features will address a range of ways first-party storage can be abused to harm users. We look forward to sharing more about these features in the coming weeks and months.

Brave will incrementally enable Forgetful Browsing for users during the 1.53 and 1.54 release processes. Users who want to test the feature now can visit brave://flags and manually enable the ‚ÄúEnable First Party Storage Cleanup support‚Äù flag. Note that Forgetful Browsing is still experimental, and should only be enabled by users who understand the risks of enabling such features. ‚Ü©Ô∏é

HTTP cached values, storage for embedded third-party iframes (in browsers other than Brave), etc. ‚Ü©Ô∏é

00:00 • 9 days ago

Wednesday, 10. May 2023

Greylock Partners

The AI Friend Zone

Tuesday, 09. May 2023

Circle Blog

Building Trust in Digital Currency

As long as money has existed, trust has been essential. It is the primary source of value for fiat currencies. Without trust, money cannot fulfill its historical functions as a store of value, a medium of exchange or a unit of account. When governments, financial institutions, and other key stakeholders in the system behave responsibly and transparently, they instill confidence in the u

As long as money has existed, trust has been essential. It is the primary source of value for fiat currencies. Without trust, money cannot fulfill its historical functions as a store of value, a medium of exchange or a unit of account. When governments, financial institutions, and other key stakeholders in the system behave responsibly and transparently, they instill confidence in the underlying financial system and associated financial assets gain in value.

When Two Giants Intersect: Healthcare Meets Fintech

Most people don‚Äôt need a reminder of the state of healthcare in America. In this episode, a16z GPs Julie You and David Haber explain where the healthcare system breaks down and how the three party system ‚Äî between payors, providers, and consumers ‚Äî can be rethought through the lens of Fintech.

As a provider of industry-leading custody solutions through its CYBAVO business unit, Circle believes the proliferation of best practices for cryptoasset custody will protect users,

On May 8th, 2023, Circle responded to the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission‚Äôs (SEC) proposal to amend its rule governing how Registered Investment Advisers (RIAs) must safeguard their clients‚Äô assets. As a provider of industry-leading custody solutions through its CYBAVO business unit, Circle believes the proliferation of best practices for cryptoasset custody will protect users, increase confidence in the cryptoasset industry, and keep investment activity in this generational technology inside of the United States.

A16Z Crypto Substack

how to build (& scale) in web3

üõ†Ô∏è Builder resources: *New* talks from our 2023 Crypto Startup School, now available! üõ†Ô∏è Builder resources: *New* talks from our 2023 Crypto Startup School, now available!

The next generation of startups isn‚Äôt just advancing web3; it‚Äôs laying the groundwork for a more open, decentralized internet. But the industry know-how, shifting trends, and emerging tools in the space can be difficult for builders to navigate ‚Äî whether they‚Äôre new to crypto, coming from other domains, or are more seasoned founders. That‚Äôs why we started Crypto Startup School in 2020, and recently relaunched it with a new cohort: to connect builders with the resources, expertise, and networks they need.

Over the past ten weeks (and counting), we‚Äôve covered topics like go-to-market, community, product-market fit, technical & research deep dives, policy, and much more. And now, we‚Äôre publicly sharing the curriculum with everyone, starting with 5 videos on: strategies for pricing; the basics of cryptography for blockchains; protocol design; the big picture; and lessons learned in strategy, growth, & operations in the business of open source (with Uniswap Labs). We‚Äôll continue to share 25+ more talks through near-weekly ‚Äúdrops‚Äù, so be sure to subscribe to our channel for updates.

watch the first batch of talks here
share: on Twitter | on LinkedIn | on Farcaster

üîóüß© Deep dive: On data availability sampling

Data availability sampling ‚Äî which is applicable to advances in computing, networking generally, and especially blockchains ‚Äî helps ensure that all necessary blockchain data has been made available to nodes without straining the network. It is therefore important for scaling blockchains.

Data availability sampling also features heavily in ‚Äúdanksharding‚Äù, a series of planned upgrades to Ethereum; and also paves the way for more advanced blockchain networks and user applications (including future stateless clients). The next danksharding milestone is EIP-4844, the Ethereum upgrade known as ‚Äúprotodanksharding‚Äù, which is planned for later this year. [Both ‚Äúdanksharding‚Äù and ‚Äúprotodanksharding‚Äù were named to reference Ethereum Foundation researchers, Dankrad Feist and protolambda (now at OP Labs).]

a16z crypto researcher & cryptographer Valeria Nikolaenko, with Stanford cryptography professor and a16z crypto research advisor Dan Boneh, survey how data availability in danksharding works. They also propose modifications to the underlying technique that may improve data recovery (e.g., requiring not 75% but 25% of shares to recover a block). Finally, both of them explain the concepts (and some of the math) involved in our latest podcast episode, hosted by a16z crypto‚Äôs Robert Hackett.

read their piece / share
listen to the discussion / share

related readings:

FAQs on danksharding & protodanksharding - Vitalik Buterin

a technical analysis of protodanksharding - Michael/ grizzly-answer-991

see/ hear also:

üìñ read about why the major Ethereum upgrade The Merge (2022) mattered - by Ali Yahya

üéß listen to ‚ÄúEthereum, the Merge and beyond‚Äù - with Tim Beiko, Tim Roughgarden, Ali Yahya, and Sonal Chokshi

üëëüîìüåê

--Sonal Chokshi, Stephanie Zinn, Tim Sullivan, Robert Hackett / a16z crypto

16:25 • 12 days ago

Nym - Medium

New mixnet integration: Nym for Monero!

New Nym mixnet integration launched for Monero desktop to secure the right to financial privacy and censorship-resistance Nym team are in Mexico City today for Monerotopia 2023 to announce that the Nym mixnet has been integrated with the Monero network! Financial privacy is an important component of digital currencies and the use of Nym will provide users with the highest level of privacy a

New Nym mixnet integration launched for Monero desktop to secure the right to financial privacy and censorship-resistance

Nym team are in Mexico City today for Monerotopia 2023 to announce that the Nym mixnet has been integrated with the Monero network!

Financial privacy is an important component of digital currencies and the use of Nym will provide users with the highest level of privacy at the infrastructure level. All users of digital currencies should be afforded equal rights to protection from financial surveillance.

A team made up of Monero community members have successfully set up a service provider to use Monero (using the Monero desktop wallet) over the Nym mixnet. This allows Monero users to easily use NymConnect to run Monero over the mixnet, thereby enhancing the privacy of Monero transactions.

How can I use Monero over the Nym mixnet?

The mainnet service provider to Monero over the Nym mixnet is now ready for use via NymConnect.

Download and open the latest version of NymConnect Click on the top left options and go to Settings Go to ‚ÄúSelect service provider‚Äù and turn it on For Mainnet, insert this service provider:
i1TiuoNp4jp9weffCW7tPnkb4hRTPydRjX8iXFVaYDG.88Z1hruuvbzWpdCE2xYnTbPNrr49j4s7mmUQC5wvRRLZ@3EPuxwGn2WP2HdxybzoDa5QsohYSP76aQQRUJuPMvk23
Go to the main NymConnect interface and connect to the mixnet

Then go to your Monero wallet (gui or otherwise) and change the settings to run over socks5 proxy:

Monero desktop: Settings -> Interface -> Socks5 proxy Monerod: add `‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääproxy 127.0.0.1:1080‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääbootstrap-daemon-proxy 127.0.0.1:1080` to args Monero-wallet-{rpc, cli}: add `‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääproxy 127.0.0.1:1080‚Ää‚Äî‚Äädaemon-ssl-allow-any-cert` to args

Follow the instructions and the Monero mainnet will be connected through to the Nym mixnet.

For those who want to try it out in testnet, a stagenet service provider is also available: https://nymtech.net/.wellknown/connect/service-providers.json

Nym Community Manager Gustavo and Nym COO Alexis in Mexico City, Monerotopia 2023 About Nym

Nym is an open-source, incentivised, and decentralised platform that protects privacy at the network level of any application, wallet or digital service. Nym protects against traffic pattern analysis and metadata surveillance. For more information: https://nymtech.net/.

About Monero

Monero was launched in April 2014. It was a fair, pre-announced launch of the CryptoNote reference code. There was no pre-mine or ‚Äúinsta‚Äù-mine, and no portion of the block reward goes to development. See the original Bitcointalk thread here.

Monero has made several large improvements since launch. Nearly all improvements have provided advances to security or privacy, or they have facilitated use. Monero continues to develop with goals of privacy and security first, ease of use and efficiency second. For more information: https://www.getmonero.org/.

Join Nym Community!

Dev chats: Element // Discord

Socials: Twitter // Discord // Telegram

Community translations

Turkish // Chinese // Russian // Portuguese // Japanese // Vietnamese

New mixnet integration: Nym for Monero! was originally published in nymtech on Medium, where people are continuing the conversation by highlighting and responding to this story.

14:07 • 12 days ago

Saturday, 06. May 2023

Verida

Join Verida‚Äôs Incentivized Testnet and Earn Tokens for Reclaiming Your Data.

Owning our personal data is both a human right and the unlock to online experiences that improve our lives and cyber safety. Verida, a privacy-first self-sovereign data network for web3, is making this possible. This week, Verida announces its upcoming incentivized testnet. The testnet is designed to provide users with an opportunity to try out the network‚Äôs functionality, offer feedback, and ear

Owning our personal data is both a human right and the unlock to online experiences that improve our lives and cyber safety. Verida, a privacy-first self-sovereign data network for web3, is making this possible.

This week, Verida announces its upcoming incentivized testnet. The testnet is designed to provide users with an opportunity to try out the network‚Äôs functionality, offer feedback, and earn rewards for their participation.

Subscribe to receive updates so you won‚Äôt miss out on our first user campaign! You can also join our self-sovereign community today to be involved in our conversations.

Our journey so far

The Verida team has built the leading decentralized self-sovereign identity tech stack over the past two years and is excited to open up access to a rapidly growing ecosystem of users, builders and partners.

We have researched, developed and deployed:

Verida Wallet, an award winning self-custody web3 ‚Äúsuper-wallet‚Äù mobile application on iOS and Android that supports decentralized identity, crypto, encrypted personal data, and a secure data inbox. Verida DID method (deployed on Polygon) which solves many critical issues with existing identity solutions to provide a fast, low cost decentralized identity viable at scale. Verida DbStore, the first truly self-sovereign encrypted storage solution for web3 that is the backbone of the Verida network and manages user-controlled, encrypted, private data for individuals. A collection of smart contracts, deployed on Polygon, that decentralize the critical components of identity, discoverability and network infrastructure for the Verida network. An incredibly powerful client SDK library for developers that enables web, mobile and server applications to leverage identities and self-sovereign storage on the Verida network. A decentralized single-sign-on toolkit that optimizes the user experience for new users and seamlessly unlocks access to encrypted data and a multi-chain blockchain wallet. A fast, encrypted, self-sovereign data testnet, running for 18 months, and recently decentralised via the Acacia testnet. Verida One (private alpha), a decentralized platform for individuals to manage all their identities and personal data in one place. A credentials incubator program, launched almost twelve months ago, and now helping multiple projects bring their credentials ecosystems to market.

We are now preparing for our mainnet, so it‚Äôs time to reward our community members for helping put the Verida testnet through its paces.

Bringing the Verida testnet to you

The incentivized testnet will rollout over several phases, each with their own campaigns. Our first phase will be focusing on end users, allowing them to install the Verida Wallet and progress through different campaigns designed to battle test the Verida network.

In future phases, the team will work closely with storage node operators and application developers to further decentralize the Verida network and build a world leading onboarding experience for web3 builders.

Why participate in the Verida incentivized testnet?

Verida‚Äôs mainnet launch is slated for mid 2023. In the leadup, the team plans to accelerate growth to onboard users, application developers and node providers onto the network. Early participants who contribute to the incentivized testnet will be rewarded with Verida‚Äôs native protocol token, VDA‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääredeemable for mainnet tokens upon launch.

More than 60% of the Verida token supply is dedicated to rewarding ecosystem participants for supporting the network rollout. A portion of this token supply will be set aside for the incentivized testnet.

What can you do?

As a user during the incentivized testnet, you can explore the many features of the Verida network and applications. You will create decentralized identities, reclaim your personal data stored in centralized platforms and unlock early access to new applications. You will download the Verida Wallet and experiment with the decentralized social platform, Verida One.

We will provide more details over the coming weeks as each campaign is announced.

What is the VDA token?

The native token of the Verida network (VDA) creates a data economy enabling secure interactions between accounts to facilitate secure data storage, trusted sharing, fast querying and secure messaging.

The Verida network is a self-sovereign ‚Äúuser-pays‚Äù model, whereby users pay for their own storage needs. In this way, ‚Äúaccess to user data‚Äù is not the product, rather the product is the ‚Äúsecurity and protection‚Äù of user data.

Storage node operators must stake VDA tokens in order for their nodes to be discoverable on the network and be available for selection by end users.

The Verida token plays an important role in bootstrapping the network by incentivizing and rewarding users for connecting their identities and data, while rewarding storage node operators for providing storage infrastructure to end users.

The Verida Data Economy

VDA has a fixed total supply of 1 billion tokens. Creating a native token allows for the design of economic incentives in the Verida network that provides control over the setting of monetary policy and equitable rewards for all network participants.

How can you participate?

Every individual has personal data to reclaim. Verida‚Äôs infrastructure will impact millions of lives. For this reason, we should all have a say. The incentivized testnet is open to everyone and all, interested in privacy-focused data management on web3.

More information will be posted on our blog in the following weeks as the Verida team prepares to launch the first user campaign. Subscribe to receive updates and join our self-sovereign community today.

This is an opportunity to contribute to a solution expected to change the nature of data on the internet. It‚Äôs about time! Join the data decentralization movement and create consensual, empowering online experiences for all.

Network Launch Schedule Verida Acacia Testnet‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäLive Verida Incentivised Acacia Testnet‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäMay 2023 Verida Myrtle Mainnet‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäQ3 2023 Own your digital identity

We‚Äôd like to take this opportunity to express our gratitude and thanks to all our community members for your interest, engagement and commitment. The Verida network is open for all, and we encourage you to bring your friends and colleagues as we embark on the next phase of the Verida network.

Learn more about Verida Build on the Verida Network Download the Verida Wallet Join the Verida One wait list Follow us on Twitter Join the conversation on Discord Explore developer documentation Ask us a question on Telegram

Join Verida‚Äôs Incentivized Testnet and Earn Tokens for Reclaiming Your Data. was originally published in Verida on Medium, where people are continuing the conversation by highlighting and responding to this story.

02:52 • 14 days ago

Friday, 05. May 2023

Horizen - Blog

Horizen Consensus 2023 Recap

We were excited to join Consensus in Austin, Texas this year as a sponsor. Connecting with our community, partners, and other projects in Web3, was incredibly rewarding and educational for our team. The post Horizen Consensus 2023 Recap appeared first on Horizen Blog.

We were excited to join Consensus in Austin, Texas this year as a sponsor. Connecting with our community, partners, and other projects in Web3, was incredibly rewarding and educational for our team.

Kicking off #Consensus2023 in style! Be sure to stop by Booth #713, grab some swag and meet our incredible team! https://t.co/0IAE6dUVhH pic.twitter.com/PF8ItXEBWI

‚Äî Horizen (@horizenglobal) April 26, 2023

Fantastic start to the final day of #consensus2023 @robviglione @Zainlabs @HorizenJordan @Angievii pic.twitter.com/NnNAyLlITB

‚Äî Horizen (@horizenglobal) April 28, 2023


This year, we showcased all that is new with the Horizen ecosystem and some of the various projects we are working on. The main focus of discussions was around our EVM-compatible sidechain, EON, which just recently launched onto the permanent public testnet, Gobi, our innovations around zero-knowledge technology, and our focus on education and documentation with our Horizen Academy, EON documentation, and more!

Horizen Presentations


The Co-Founder of Horizen and Horizen Labs, Rob Viglione, led a presentation on Why Enterprises Haven‚Äôt Embraced Blockchain En Masse. The presentation focused on scale, privacy, and control on the final day of Consensus. After his talk, Rob was joined by Zain Cheng, CTO of Horizen Labs, and Jordan Calinoff, VP of Strategy and Revenue at Horizen Labs for a panel discussion moderated by Angie Villarreal, Project Manager at Horizen Labs.


The Horizen dAppy Hour

Horizen hosted a side event during Consensus, called dAppy Hour, with our partners Horizen Labs, Immunefi, Zellic, and Auros, where guests enjoyed food, drinks, and networking! We had live music at the event, featured an interactive photo booth, and it was a great opportunity for Consensus attendees to network and unwind, during a busy event week, welcoming over 300 attendees throughout the evening!


Final Thoughts

Consensus was a great opportunity for the team to catch up with our community, learn more about what the latest in Web3 was, meet our new ecosystem partners, and more. We look forward to seeing everyone again next year.

The post Horizen Consensus 2023 Recap appeared first on Horizen Blog.

15:14 • 14 days ago

Nym - Medium

Nym in Rio de Janeiro: putting privacy on the mainstage of WebSummit

Centre stage fireside chat between Chelsea Manning (Nym) and Leo Swartz (Fortune)‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäWebSummit Rio 2023 Nym was at WebSummit in Rio this week, one of the world‚Äôs largest technology conferences. The team joined other innovators, thought leaders and entrepreneurs from across the world with the aim to ensure privacy remains at the centre of internet industry debates, and to support the rapidly gro
Centre stage fireside chat between Chelsea Manning (Nym) and Leo Swartz (Fortune)‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäWebSummit Rio 2023

Nym was at WebSummit in Rio this week, one of the world‚Äôs largest technology conferences. The team joined other innovators, thought leaders and entrepreneurs from across the world with the aim to ensure privacy remains at the centre of internet industry debates, and to support the rapidly growing Latin American Nym community!

Nym joined forces with Signal to ensure privacy was the headline of WebSummit with centre stage appearances by Chelsea Manning and shortly after by the President of Signal messaging app, Meredith Whittacker. The two voices ensured that the AI hype was grounded in the realities of data markets and centralised power, emphasising the need for privacy technologies to ensure our future freedoms!

Key highlights from this week Nym Security Chelsea Manning opened the centre stage in a fireside chat with Forbes crypto reporter Leo Swartz and featured as the main conference highlight of the day. The Nym Masterclass on Privacy in the Age of AI had a guest appearance by President of Signal foundation, Meredith Whittaker, and was packed way over capacity. The Nym partnership with Swissnex was strengthened boost growth in Latin America, hosting presentations by Nym COO Alexis Roussel, CSO Jaya Klara Brekke and Head of Growth Daniel Vazquez. Nym team met with the Rio Secretary for Science and Innovation to propose a Rio privacy crypto-carnival (and she liked it! So stay tuned for a party invitation‚Ä¶) The Nym community of Rio linked up with the z-cash community to boost privacy interest and ecosystem growth in the region. Brazil takes on the tech industry

Just before WebSummit opened, Brazil shut down Telegram for a few days. The Brazilian Congress is going through an intense debate about a new online bill to push for stronger content moderation by technology platforms, after far right groups attacked government buildings and schools earlier in the year.

Privacy is the solution, not the problem

The new bill and how to address manipulation, radicalisation and violence, without resorting to censorship was a major topic of discussion at the Summit. But there is an approach to these problems that so far has been overlooked: strong privacy protections. Securing strong privacy of communications would protect people from being profiled and targeted with radicalising content streams and misinformation!

Nym discussed the problem of disinformation with the Secretary of Science and Innovation of Rio de Janeiro, Tatiana Roque, who is also an expert on the topic. In her view, trusted social relationships provide the societal immune system to solve misinformation and disinformation. And she agreed that enabling people to securely communicate with one another without spying and interference is the foundation for building trust in society.

Fireside Chat with Chelsea Manning, Nym and Leo Swartz, Fortune

Tuesday 2nd of May, 10.30 am centre stage‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääwatch here

How could strong data privacy lead to better AI? Could encryption democratise governance and access to AI? How can cryptography counter deep-fakes and contribute to a better and more secure online experience? Chelsea Manning spoke on MainStage with journalist Leo Schwartz, reporter at Fortune covering the global impact of crypto, regulation, cyber crime, and all things blockchain.

Nym Masterclass: Privacy in the age of AI

Tuesday 2nd of May, 1pm Main Conference, Masterclass 3

Unfortunately WebSummit does not record masterclasses, but a longer summary is coming!

Chelsea Manning, Jaya Klara Brekke, Meredith Whittaker, Alexis Roussel and Vincent Neumann at the Nym Masterclass on Privacy in the age of AI‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäWebSummit Rio 2023

A major highlight of the whole summit was the Nym masterclass on Privacy and AI. The Nym team Jaya Klara Brekke, Alexis Roussel and Chelsea Manning, was joined by President of Signal Foundation, Meredith Whittaker and Vincent Neumann, Program Manager, Innovation & Startups Swissnex (in order of appearance). We had a queue down two floors and the room filled up over capacity!

AI has been built after over a decade of mass surveillance. In the words of Meredith: it is a ‚Äúsurveillance derivative‚Äù. The recent boom is the result of large technology platforms holding near monopoly access to people‚Äôs content and behavioural data. But privacy preserving technologies are going through their own revolution. End-to-end encryption is becoming standard and we now have functioning mixnets and advanced cryptographic techniques including homomorphic encryption.

The key question is whether these technologies can ensure that people and society can have a say over the future development and uses of AI. Privacy preserving technologies afterall place the power to decide over data (when it is created and who can use it) back into the hands of people.

Jaya introduced the session, providing the current context of AI hype, privacy tech and the risks of ‚Äúprivacy washing‚Äù that will likely come this next year.

Alexis gave an overview of the Nym mixnet, and how metadata can be protected to secure against AI-powered surveillance.

Chelsea emphasised that regulation is not going to be enough, what is needed is a technological intervention to block data markets and shift the direction of AI development.

Meredith gave the historical overview of how data-markets and centralised big tech power emerged to monopolise the control over AI, reproducing racist categorisations in society. Important research and publications that were mentioned included the AI Now report by Amba Kak and Dr Sarah Myers West, work by Abeba Birhane and work by Prof Louise Amoore.

Vincent Neuman of Swissnex rounded off the masterclass highlighting the importance of Latin America as a counterpoint to the surveillance-driven technology industries of the US and China, describing the work and programs of Swissnex in supporting start ups in the region.

Press conference with Alexis Roussel and Chelsea Manning

The Nym WebSummit press conference on building privacy by design‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääwatch here.

Chelsea Manning (Nym) and Alexis Roussel (Nym) press conference‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäWebSummit Rio 2023 The Nym team on the ground in Rio Nym Latin America Daniel Vazquez (Head of growth in Latin America) Joao Phelip (Nym community manager, Portuguese) With expert assistance on the booth from Paula and Bruno! Nym Europe and US Alexis Roussel (COO) Jaya Klara Brekke (CSO) Chelsea Manning, Nym security consultant

Thank you Rio de Janeiro!

Nym team and partners from Instituto Educar+ at the Nym booth‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäWebSummit Rio 2023Nym and z-cash community‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääbecause privacy love company!Nym and z-cash communities at WebSummit Rio Join Nym community

Telegram Portugu√™s // Twitter Portugu√™s

Discord // Telegram // Twitter

Community translations

Turkish // Russian

Nym in Rio de Janeiro: putting privacy on the mainstage of WebSummit was originally published in nymtech on Medium, where people are continuing the conversation by highlighting and responding to this story.

07:51 • 15 days ago

Panther Protocol

Monthly Update: April 2023

Just like every month, it‚Äôs time for monthly update. As we start May at full speed, let's take a moment to recap April‚Äôs developments!

Dear Panthers,

Just like every month, it‚Äôs time for a monthly update. As we start May at full speed, let's take a moment to recap April‚Äôs developments!

Tech updates v0.5 updates PIP-13 succeeded!

Earlier this month, a series of updates and upgrades for v0.5 was presented by the Panther community. This elaborate proposal aimed to introduce updates to v0.5 needed for v1‚Äôs development and launch a new Advanced Staking round.

Formalizing this proposal, PIP-13 succeeded with an overwhelming majority vote on our Snapshot page. Among other things, this meant that the community decided on:

Prolonging the "Advanced Staking" program, conserving the original staking APR, until Aug 22, 2023 Implementing UI upgrades, effectively elevating v0.5 to Panther Protocol‚Äôs v0.5.3.

After the vote, the proposal was successfully executed. With all contracts deployed by Panther community members, this is officially our third decentralized deployment to date!

v1 updates Testing for v1

We keep working on Panther's v1 mechanism to issue rewards, with complex mathematical models running to test this. Work on rewards and fees is now unblocked due to advancements in Shielded Pools' development and the deployment of v0.5.3, a significant step forward.

General product testing for v1 is also progressing according to plan. This month witnessed the internal release of the first prototype for the full product. Exciting times are near as we polish and prepare to develop it towards Testnet!

Get ready for v1! Diving into zSwap and DeFi Adaptors Panther will enable private DEX swaps with zSwap.

We also just published an article featuring an in-depth look at zSwap & DeFi Adaptors.

Discover how this concept will link Panther with leading DeFi dApps like Uniswap, QuickswapDEX, and Curve Finance, enabling seamless & private swaps on DEXs. The article also explains how having DeFi Adaptors makes Panther‚Äôs privacy stronger.

Relayer integration

For v1, we are also progressing in the integration of relayers, an essential component of Panther‚Äôs privacy.

Relayers are responsible for forwarding transactions to the blockchain, thus acting as intermediaries between Panther‚Äôs privacy layer and the decentralized network. They can do so, for example, by paying for gas in users‚Äô name. By integrating relayers, we aim to significantly increase privacy by obfuscating the origin of transactions, making it more difficult for third parties to trace and link them to specific users.

Another crucial aspect of our ongoing work is the exploration of gasless transactions. Gas fees are a well-known pain point for users in the blockchain ecosystem, often causing frustration due to their volatility and unpredictability. By evaluating gasless transactions, we hope to provide users with a more convenient and cost-effective way to interact with the Panther Protocol network.

Lastly, we are in the process of exploring Account Abstraction Paymaster logic. Account abstraction is a cutting-edge technique that aims to simplify the user experience by allowing smart contracts to pay gas fees on behalf of users. The Paymaster logic plays a crucial role in this process, as it is responsible for determining which transactions should be paid for and ensuring the appropriate gas fees are covered.

Panther‚Äôs PMONK zero-knowledge scheme makes its debut Last weekend, at the ETH Privacy event in Istanbul, Turkey, CTO and Chief Scientist Anish Mohammed presented a paper for PMONK, Panther‚Äôs original zk-SNARK scheme.

This presentation, which will be soon published on Youtube, represents a significant milestone in the history of our project. There is still quite some way to go before we can tell you more about PMONK‚Äôs applications, but right now seemed like a good time to share the excitement!

Documentation review, compliance work, and website continue to progress

Last but not least, our technical contributors are fact-checking and screening our improved documentation for it to go live.

Expect the site‚Äôs launch soon, as well as a first release of documentation followed by an ongoing process of updates and upgrades.

Finally, we continue engaging with industry leaders in the Web3 compliance realm to determine the best approach for Panther's solution. Stay tuned!

Ecosystem Community-driven exchange listings Another mission successfully completed by the Panther DAO!

This month, our decentralized community reached a notable milestone as $ZKP was listed on MEXC Global in a community-driven operation, enhancing our token‚Äôs accessibility in the crypto ecosystem.

Following this, Hotbit.io also took the initiative to list $ZKP, so we had two centralized exchange listings this month.

ZKPanthers NFT giveaway Cool cats.

Another notable event this was the #ZKPanthers NFT giveaway organized by community merch providers Subverted Norms!

Subverted Norms designed the beautiful artwork, minting only 25 tokens, giving away 15 of them, and listing the rest for sale at OpenSea. They also created some cool products based on this NFTs, which you can see on their merch shop!

Congratulations to all the winners!

Media and articles

Co-Founder Oliver Gale's latest piece on the potential of zero-knowledge proofs (ZKPs) and their use cases for businesses is now live on Forbes. The article discusses the importance of ZKPs in finance, as they enable secure and private transactions while meeting regulatory requirements. The article also highlights how businesses can benefit from ZKPs in terms of enhanced privacy, improved security, regulatory compliance, and greater efficiency.

Read it here.

A read you can‚Äôt miss straight from our CEO.

Oliver also published two more articles on our blog:

The first one breaks down the potential role of on-chain dark pools as key to attracting traditional institutions and enterprises to DeFi. He explains how these pools can allow for secure, private, and regulatory-compliant transactions that leverage the best side of decentralized finance. Read it here. The second one was written in anticipation of Consensus 2023, the largest gathering of crypto, blockchain, and Web3 communities. In it, Oliver highlights the critical industry concerns and insights on integrating traditional finance and DeFi, addressing regulatory compliance, exploring compliant-friendly data protection solutions like Zero-Knowledge technology, and fostering collaboration for a unified financial ecosystem. Read it here. Ama with Hotbit

Oliver also took part in an AMA hosted by Hotbit to introduce Panther to a broader audience and answer questions about his latest article mentioned above. To all of you new here, welcome!

Hotbit AMA with Oliver Gale. Clips, podcasts and video

Our other Co-founder, Anish Mohammed, was also featured in some insightful clips this month:
1Ô∏è) The crucial need for privacy in the #DeFi realm.

Panther‚Äôs v1 will empowers users to leverage their existing assets with enhanced privacy.

Co-founder @anishmohammed delves into the crucial need for privacy in the #DeFi realm. pic.twitter.com/lCLrrKxIDi

‚Äî Panther Protocol (@ZKPanther) April 11, 2023


2Ô∏è) How Panther is a much-needed layer of privacy for #DeFi.

Panther v1‚Äôs privacy-enhancing features will enable retail and institutions to take advantage of what #DeFi has to offer with an added layer of privacy.

Co-founder @anishmohammed draws a parallel with banks in the traditional world.üè¶ pic.twitter.com/XqqkngzfQK

‚Äî Panther Protocol (@ZKPanther) April 13, 2023

Co-founder & CEO Oliver Gale also appeared on the CryptoNews podcast, discussing crypto regulation and Panther's innovative approach to combining compliance with privacy.

Events

Oliver Gale and Head of Product Saif Akhtar attended #Consensus2023 by CoinDesk to meet key players from all sides of the crypto, blockchain, and the Web3 ecosystem this April 26-28.

Oliver Gale & Saif Akhtar at Consensus2023

Head of Product Saif was also invited to speak at NFT NYC 2023, where he shared his expertise on the significance of privacy within the NFT space. He also spoke at Michigan‚Äôs State University about the importance of financial privacy and usecases of Panther.

Panther‚Äôs Head of Product Saif Akhtar at MSU.

Finally April, Panther contributors came together to attend the Leading Privacy Alliance‚Äôs ZK9 Summit and meet other builders in the ZK space. It‚Äôs always great to catch up!

Panther contributors at the #ZK9 Summit. About Panther

Panther is a decentralized protocol that enables interoperable privacy in DeFi using zero-knowledge proofs.

Users can mint fully-collateralized, composable tokens called zAssets, which can be used to execute private, trusted DeFi transactions across multiple blockchains.

Panther helps investors protect their personal financial data and trading strategies, and provides financial institutions with a clear path to compliantly participate in DeFi.

Website ¬∑ One-pager ¬∑ Lite Paper ¬∑ Twitter ¬∑ Telegram ¬∑ Discord

Andreesen Horowitz - a16z

Embracing the Future: How Chatbots Can Become Great Companions

17:15 • 15 days ago

Sequoia

Sequoia Open Source Fellowship

The post Sequoia Open Source Fellowship appeared first on Sequoia Capital US/Europe.
New Fellowship: How Sequoia is Supporting Open Source

FastAPI creator Sebasti√°n Ram√≠rez is the first recipient of the Sequoia Open Source Fellowship.

By Bogomil Balkansky and Lauren Reeder Published May 4, 2023

Open source is the lifeblood of software. Downloads of the most popular open source packages are measured in the trillions and growing fast, and most commercial software today features libraries and programs made better and more reliable by open source contributors around the world. At Sequoia, we have a long history of partnering with companies that pioneered the commercialization of open source software, such as MongoDB and Confluent, and the pace of our partnerships with open source companies  is also on the rise, including Chainguard, Deno, dbt labs, Infracost and Temporal Technologies in recent years. But we also recognize that open source projects that don‚Äôt become businesses are still critical tools for our portfolio companies and the broader community.

Last year, we were fortunate enough to meet Sebasti√°n Ram√≠rez, creator of the wildly popular open source Python framework FastAPI, which is used everywhere from Fortune Global 500 corporations such as BMW, American Express and Roche, to academia, to nonprofits such as NASA and the Red Cross. Sebasti√°n was overflowing with ideas to improve on what he‚Äôd built‚Äîbut because even the most beloved open source projects rarely pay the bills, he was forced to split his time between FastAPI and part-time work.

His situation inspired us to think about how we might support his work and that of other open source creators who give so much to the broader tech ecosystem. Today, we are thrilled to share that Sebasti√°n is the first Sequoia Open Source Fellow.

Each year, we‚Äôll invite a small number of leading open source contributors to this new fellowship program and will provide a stipend to cover their living expenses for 6 to 12 months, so they can dedicate themselves to their open source work full-time. They‚Äôll also become members of the Sequoia community, connecting with and mentoring founders. (Sebasti√°n recently helped us host the closing event for our seed-stage catalyst, Arc.) In short, we will support each other. We believe Sequoia can benefit greatly from fellows‚Äô expertise to help us better understand the open source ecosystem, but there are no other strings attached. Our goal is to give Sebasti√°n and builders like him the time and space to innovate, whatever that means for them. 

We recently sat down with Sebasti√°n to talk about FastAPI, his fellowship experience so far, and what‚Äôs next.

For those who aren‚Äôt familiar, what is FastAPI and why did you build it?

Sebasti√°n: FastAPI makes life easier for developers working in applications in the cloud using Python, which is one of the most popular programming languages‚Äîit‚Äôs often used for machine learning, data science and AI. You can use FastAPI to take advantage of all the features of code editors, like auto completion and inline errors, while getting application best practices by default with simple code, all in one place, so you can be super efficient and still get the best possible quality and performance.

I was working on teams building data and machine learning products, and we kept seeing the same problems and mistakes. I tried every tool I could find, but nothing ticked all the boxes‚Äîso eventually, I decided to try to put all the things I liked about other frameworks into one project. I didn‚Äôt expect it to work, but it did! I released the first public version of FastAPI on December 24, 2018, two years after the version of Python that enabled FastAPI, and it‚Äôs been downloaded more than 800,000 times since. It was even used to share data captured by the James Webb Space Telescope‚Äîthat was a highlight.

Data captured by the James Webb telescope was shared via FastAPI.

Why did you decide this fellowship was right for you?

Sebasti√°n: Ever since I started FastAPI, I‚Äôd been trying to optimize to work more on it and my other open source projects, like Typer and SQLModel. But because they were growing so quickly, it took a lot of time just to maintain them, and even more to improve them. I quit my job and worked part-time, but it still wasn‚Äôt enough. So doing open source exclusively was super appealing‚Äînot just the hours, but the continuity of those hours. I knew being able to focus deeply would drive a lot more progress.

I was also interested in learning about how businesses are built, because I think for FastAPI, a self-sustaining model will probably make sense at some point. It can help a lot of people and organizations be more efficient, and there‚Äôs value in that. But I wanted to focus first on just making it the best tool possible.

What has the experience been like so far?

Amazing. Honestly, I didn‚Äôt expect it to be this nice. We had calls before we started, and those were good. It was good on paper. But it‚Äôs been just as it was on those calls. We talk about companies and projects, but otherwise, I get to just work like crazy.

One thing that‚Äôs really valuable but less obvious is that I can focus on what I know will have the biggest impact, even if it‚Äôs invisible to most users‚Äîlike the underlying building blocks of FastAPI, or even other open source projects it uses. I‚Äôve even been working on improving the way internal code (reference) APIs are documented in Python itself recently, which is the kind of thing it‚Äôs usually very difficult to allocate time and resources for. But it will be super valuable, for FastAPI users and everyone else.

What are you most looking forward to‚Äîduring the rest of your fellowship and beyond?

A bunch of things! The most obvious one is integration for the new version of Pydantic, which is now part of the Sequoia community, too. It‚Äôs going to mean a big boost in performance for FastAPI and the other tools, plus better support for edge cases. I‚Äôm also working on more documentation of FastAPI‚Äôs internal code‚ÄîI have lots of tutorials, but there isn‚Äôt a dictionary-like code API reference, which is one of the things people request the most. And I‚Äôm making improvements to FastAPI itself, and to Typer, SQLModel, Asyncer, and others, which will simplify building the whole stack in FastAPI applications.

I‚Äôm also looking forward to continuing all the relationships I‚Äôve built, including with you two! I was always scared of VCs. The idea of raising capital and building a company wasn‚Äôt super intuitive to me. But this has been a mindset shift‚Äîseeing that it can actually be good. We‚Äôre friends! It feels like, ‚ÄúOkay, this really can work.‚Äù

Consideration for the Sequoia Open Source Fellowship is by invitation only; we aim to support established creators and enable them to chart the paths of their projects as they continue to grow. If you‚Äôre interested in learning more, contact us here.

Lauren, Sebasti√°n and Bogomil at Sequoia. Share Share this on Facebook Share this on Twitter Share this on LinkedIn Share this via email

The post Sequoia Open Source Fellowship appeared first on Sequoia Capital US/Europe.

Euro Coin is a fully reserved, euro-backed stablecoin that is always redeemable 1-for-1 for euros MB users can now access near-instant foreign exchange from local currency to euros

S√£o Paulo, May 3, 2023 ‚Äî MB (Mercado Bitcoin), the largest digital asset platform in Latin America, now lists Circle Internet Financial‚Äôs euro-backed stablecoin, Euro Coin, on its platform. Euro Coin, which uses the token symbol EUROC, is issued on the Ethereum network and can be used with any ERC-20 compatible wallet, app, or DeFi protocol.
