13:09 • 2 months ago

Brave Browser

Brave Launches Self-Serve Ads Program

Today, Brave is launching its Self-Serve Ads Program. These new tools allow brands to set up and run advertising for their products and services within the privacy-preserving Brave Ads and Rewards ecosystem.

Today, Brave is launching its Self-Serve Ads Program. These new tools allow brands to set up and run advertising for their products and services within the privacy-preserving Brave Ads and Rewards ecosystem. This is an important next step on our roadmap for Brave and the Basic Attention Token (BAT) to provide effective advertising that protects users‚Äô privacy.

The Brave Ads Self-Serve Program allows brands to set up and run ad campaigns in the Brave Browser and Search ecosystem with minimal assistance from the Brave team. Initially, the Brave Ads Self-Serve Program invites brands to run English-language campaigns in countries currently supported by Brave Ads. We plan to introduce support for additional languages over time.

The program is also an opportunity for brands who are new to Brave to join, and provide feedback and to improve our Brave Ads products.

The Self-Serve Program offers the ability for brands to purchase campaigns to run in the Brave Ads Push Notification ad unit. Over time, the team will be introducing Brave News Ads and Brave Search Ads units to self-serve to be available to directly purchase within the platform.

Advertisers participating in the program will also receive beta access to new self-serve features as we introduce them into the system over time, and will have the opportunity to provide direct feedback and have access to our Brave Ads Product and Brave Research teams. 

Brave‚Äôs direct sales team will continue to sell New Tab Takeovers (formerly named Sponsored Images). These assets will not be available within self-serve given the curated image selection and approval process. However, if program participants express interest in purchasing Sponsored Images, they will be connected with our Sales team to help facilitate that process.

A minimum campaign spend of $1,000 USD per month is required to participate in the self-serve program. Advertisers are required to pre-pay, with either BAT or USD.

Advertisers enrolled in the Brave Ads Self-Serve Program are eligible to receive a 50% discount on their first campaign, if they purchase their campaign with BAT. Additional campaign discounts for purchasing campaigns with BAT will be available throughout the program. 

Our current advertising policies will apply to brands in the program; human review will remain a part of the process to ensure the safety of Brave‚Äôs users, and preserve the integrity of our brand and product.

Background

Brave Ads were first launched in early 2019, available to Brave users who opted-in to Brave Rewards, from Brave‚Äôs 5.5 million monthly active user base at the time. The concept of advertising with privacy was new to most advertisers (and Brave‚Äôs ad platform remains a unique offering still in 2023), so Brave Ads were brought to market as a managed service to help educate and learn with our customers. Brave‚Äôs teams of sellers, account managers, operations, finance, and engineering work together to bring in customers and deploy their campaigns into the Brave ecosystem. The managed service approach helps Brave provide white glove service with education on Brave and Brave Ads, while keeping an established onboarding and payment process in place that brands are familiar with.

Brave has since grown significantly, with our user base now at 57 million monthly and 21 million daily active users. The Brave Ads platform and offerings have also grown from one ad unit to four ad units across various Brave products that brands can use to communicate their story and grow their customer base. Brave Search ads are also rolling out and will get access to our 23 million daily queries and over 8 billion annualized queries.

Brave Ads campaigns have also been supported in nearly 200 countries with over 7.5 billion ad confirmation events to date, and there have been over 6,600 campaigns since the inception from over 900 advertisers, from mainstream brands such as Ford, PayPal, Toyota, Mastercard, Intel, Chipotle, Crocs, BMW, Keurig, American Express, Budweiser, Walmart, Amazon, and The Home Depot, as well as from crypto giants like Binance, Coinbase, eToro, Ledger, NEAR, and Solana. The time has come for Brave to bring the Brave Ads Self-Serve Program to market, and grow the ecosystem even further.

Getting Started

Brands looking to participate in the program can head over to our Brave Ads Self-Serve Program page to learn more, or to complete and submit the form to join the program‚Äôs waitlist. The Brave Ads team will be onboarding groups of advertisers from the waitlist, based on available supply across Brave Ads inventory.

We are excited to enter the next phase of the Brave Ads and Rewards ecosystem with the introduction of the Self-Serve Program, as the Ads platform becomes easily accessible to a broader range of global brands and marketers.

Zcash Foundation

Minor Grants Applications

In February, we announced a new, experimental Zcash Foundation (ZF) grants program, nicknamed ‚ÄúMinor Grants‚Äù, for smaller grants of up to $25,000. We‚Äôre pleased to present ten applications that were submitted to this program, and which passed our internal suitability review. Here are links to the grant applications (in PDF format), listed in alphabetical order: [‚Ä¶]

In February, we announced a new, experimental Zcash Foundation (ZF) grants program, nicknamed ‚ÄúMinor Grants‚Äù, for smaller grants of up to $25,000.

We‚Äôre pleased to present ten applications that were submitted to this program, and which passed our internal suitability review. Here are links to the grant applications (in PDF format), listed in alphabetical order:

Algorithmic Anthropometry Aprendamos de Criptos y Blockchain (trans. Let‚Äôs learn about Crypto and Blockchain) Crew3 technician Dizzy Wallet: A Dedicated Zcash Wallet for Discord Preparing and publishing a web novel dealing with financial privacy in crypto Research on Zcash‚Äôs KYC-Free Infrastructure Uang di Masa Depan: A Personal Finance Course for Under-privileged Youth Unified Address parsing and construction library for .NET Zcash Zeitgeist 02 Zcast, el podcast de Zcash en EspanÃÉol

Later today, we will open a poll of the Zcash Community Advisory Panel (ZCAP) to determine which of these applications will be funded. The poll will close at 09:00 UTC on 17th April 2023.

As the total amount requested ($59,987) is less than the program budget ($75,000), any application that receives greater than 50% approval from the participants in the ZCAP poll will be funded.

But what‚Äôs going to happen? Lyn has the answers.  ------ ‚ú® DEBRIEF | Unpack

Lyn Alden is one of crypto‚Äôs favorite macro commentators and also a frequent returning guest to the Bankless program. When Lyn comes on Bankless, you know it‚Äôs because Macro is confusing, and we need help navigating these chaotic waters. 

Inflation! Bank run! Insolvency! Recession! Everyone‚Äôs yelling things! But what‚Äôs going to happen? Lyn has the answers. 

------ ‚ú® DEBRIEF | Unpacking the episode:  https://www.bankless.com/debrief-lyn-alden    ------ In today‚Äôs episode, Lyn covers whether or not the Fed Balance sheet is expanding to infinity, what‚Äôs even on the Fed Balance sheet, how the Fed actually works, why a regional bank crisis might domino to the Dollar losing world reserve currency status, and how that same bank crisis might impact the 2024 US Election. 

This is a Lyn Alden episode you don‚Äôt want to miss.

Sunday, 02. April 2023

Panther Protocol

Monthly Update - March 2023

We are delighted to showcase the milestones and accomplishments that have shaped our progress over the past month. Let‚Äôs take a good look at March 2023!

Dear Panthers,

In this end-of-quarter update, we are delighted to showcase the milestones and accomplishments that have shaped our progress over the past month. Along with our regular monthly progress update, we are also happy to review our performance over Q1 2023 against our freshly-published roadmap.

As we continue to grow and innovate, we remain grateful for the unwavering support of our thriving community. Let‚Äôs take a good look at March 2023!

Roadmap and Quarterly achievements Say hi to our new Roadmap!

Panther Protocol‚Äôs first three quarters of 2023.

This month, we released our roadmap for 2023-2024! It outlines all the upcoming milestones for Panther‚Äôs v1 deployment. Dive into our recent Twitter thread to see the different components and use cases that we plan to roll out in the journey toward v1.

As Q1 2023 is coming to an end, let‚Äôs see how we fared in meeting our quarterly goals for it.

Q1 2023

As we enter Q2, we are thrilled to announce the successful implementation of some key initiatives that mark a significant milestone in our journey toward decentralization and privacy solutions for institutions and retail users alike.

New website

Firstly, our new website is being coded into existence as you read this. And‚Ä¶

Ta-da! We‚Äôre debuting a new image and style for our revamped site.

The new site introduces a style, brand, and messaging change. As Product and compliance design are cemented and brought into life, we‚Äôre increasingly confident in the utility Panther can and will have for institutions. This look is meant to reflect it. Accordingly, the contents of the website will reflect a more comprehensive look at our Product‚Äôs capabilities and use cases.

As per ‚Äúa chain-agnostic privacy layer,‚Äù we believe this term nicely overcomes one of our most complex branding and marketing challenges to date: explaining Panther in a short sentence. ‚ÄúChain-agnostic‚Äù refers to how you will be able to access Panther‚Äôs privacy from many different chains, with no preference towards any L1 or L2, while also being able to move between chains. Meanwhile, ‚Äúprivacy layer‚Äù refers to how Panther‚Äôs ecosystem benefits from a shared privacy set, allowing users of different chains to privately access DeFi while having the right to opt between privacy and transparency, getting in and out of the privacy layer.

We can‚Äôt wait for you to see the rest of the changes we‚Äôre introducing!

Improved documentation
A sneak peek into our new documentation structure (but there is more!)

In addition to the website revamp, we have also finished updates to Panther‚Äôs documentation, marking the beginning of a new era where documentation will be a live process with constant updates and growth.

Our updated documentation is more intuitive and user-friendly, with sections dedicated to stakeholders, retail users, and financial institutions. Furthermore, the new documentation covers essential topics such as Panther‚Äôs approach to zero-knowledge proofs (ZKPs) and zk-SNARKS. We've also updated critical sections on MASPs, fee structures, DeFi adaptors, and cryptographic primitives.

While some sections are still a work in progress, this approach marks a significant departure from our previous static documentation approach and underscores our commitment to continuous improvement. The documentation itself is experiencing its final review and will be live for you to see it soon!

$ZKP is being listed in MEXC

PIP-12 on Snapshot

In February, PIP-12 was passed with an approval rating of 98.97%. This proposal involved listing $ZKP on MEXC Global, a well-known and trusted centralized exchange. In light of this, we initiated the listing process.

The MEXC listing is particularly significant as it will allow Panther users to deposit and withdraw ZKP on Polygon, which complements Panther‚Äôs v1 release.

Moreover, the Panther DAO sees the decision to list on MEXC as a strategic move to enhance the Panther ecosystem‚Äôs liquidity.

On their side, MEXC Global has commenced voting for the listing of $ZKP as part of its pre-launch listing campaign. This process allows users to stake tokens and cast their votes in support of their preferred project, with the chance to get some tokens airdropped to them. MEXC's goal is to identify and promote high-quality projects to its community, and this listing campaign serves as a crucial filter for achieving that objective. The voting period for $ZKP's listing runs from 2023-04-04 at 12:00 to 2023-04-04 at 21:50 (UTC).

MEXC‚Äôs Community Voting for $ZKP on MEXC‚Äôs Kickstarter platform is now live. Governance framework development

Finally, as part of Phase 2 of our decentralization phase, we have made solid steps towards formalizing a much-awaited governance framework.

The Panther community has settled on appointing a Council as the last step toward formalizing this framework. The Council will have the core responsibility of vetting which DAO proposals are suitable to move into voting by the Panther community i.e., whether they can be objectively beneficial for the project in the long term.

This discussion is still ongoing on Panther‚Äôs Discourse forum, with the community discussing the onboarding process and metrics. Feel free to join it and participate!

Technology updates
A busy month as we prepare for v1‚Äôs Testnet

As our Roadmap shows, Q2 2023 will see the release of Panther‚Äôs v1 Testnet, and, as such, many things are developing behind the scenes.

Among these milestones are critical components of smart contracts for fees and rewards on v1, which have already been developed and are pending connection to a Multi-Asset Shielded Pool (MASP).  Panther is currently clarifying the parameters for rewarding to crystallize the model before v1's MASP is finished. Contracts are almost finalized, and progress is ongoing in the area of data modeling.

On the KYC/KYT integration front, Panther is currently interacting with other specialists in the DeFi ecosystem to build a comprehensive solution to support compliance attestations and disclosures. We‚Äôre getting ready for a significant informational release regarding this component that will be core to Panther disrupting the PriFi scene.

Simultaneously, planning for the v1 dApp continues, with major progress on the UI front. This means that the development of the fully-planned dApp is expected to begin soon.

Panther's DeFi Adaptors design has also been solidified and is ready to become a functional interface. Additional UTXO variable functionalities were added to production too, which we will discuss in greater detail in an upcoming article.

By the way, did you see this alpha drop related to Panther‚Äôs cryptography research?

Panther‚Äôs SNARK Research paper will be presented in Istanbul this month. v0.5.2 Upgrades and UI Development

A DAO proposal is underway to introduce a community deployment of v0.5.2, an upgrade that features several improvements vital to building v1.

Simultaneously, the Panther community is discussing terms for extending the v0.5 Advanced Staking program.

See you in CdMX! About Panther

Panther is a decentralized protocol that enables interoperable privacy in DeFi using zero-knowledge proofs.

Users can mint fully-collateralized, composable tokens called zAssets, which can be used to execute private, trusted DeFi transactions across multiple blockchains.

Panther helps investors protect their personal financial data and trading strategies, and provides financial institutions with a clear path to compliantly participate in DeFi.

Friday, 31. March 2023

Epicenter Podcast

Barry: Dymension ‚Äì Modular Blockchains and RollApps

When it comes to scaling blockchains, there are 2 main types of off-chain solutions: sidechains and L2s (i.e. rollups, state channels). These are all intended to scale monolithic L1 blockchains. However, the core functional layers of a blockchain could also be reinvisioned as customisable building blocks. This idea led to the creation of modular blockchains, which handle execution, consensus and d

When it comes to scaling blockchains, there are 2 main types of off-chain solutions: sidechains and L2s (i.e. rollups, state channels). These are all intended to scale monolithic L1 blockchains. However, the core functional layers of a blockchain could also be reinvisioned as customisable building blocks. This idea led to the creation of modular blockchains, which handle execution, consensus and data availability separately from one another, thus considerably increasing throughput.
Dymension is a Cosmos modular blockchain hub that acts as settlement layer for RollApps (app-specific chains).

Sebastien was joined by Barry, Head of Product at Dymension, to discuss the advantages of developing modular blockchains, their scalability and how RollApps integrate in this environment.

Topics covered in this episode:

Barry‚Äôs background The evolution of scaling solutions & Dymension‚Äôs RollApps The nuances of different types of rollups (L1 vs. L2, Ethereum vs. Cosmos) The scalability trilemma and modular blockchains Cosmos‚Äô ICS scaling The architecture of Dymension and its RDK How RollApps choose the data availability layer RollApp interoperability Incentivising sequencer neutrality Network roles in Dymension and differences between SDK & RDK Use cases & limitations of RollApps Future roadmap

Episode links:

Barry on Twitter Dymension on Twitter Dymension's website The Interop Podcast on Twitter Celestia on Twitter

This episode is hosted by Sebastien Couture. Show notes and listening options: epicenter.tv/489

a16z Podcast

Digital Humans and the Story Behind Lil Miquela

You‚Äôve probably heard of ‚ÄòLil Miquela. The 19 year-old Brazilian-American inÔ¨Çuencer has millions of followers and has partnered with the likes of Samsung and Prada. But despite capturing the hearts of many, she‚Äôs not real.  But you probably haven‚Äôt heard her origin story. In this episode we take a trip back to 2016, to a world that looked much different to today, together with two of Miquela

You‚Äôve probably heard of ‚ÄòLil Miquela. The 19 year-old Brazilian-American inÔ¨Çuencer has millions of followers and has partnered with the likes of Samsung and Prada. But despite capturing the hearts of many, she‚Äôs not real. 

But you probably haven‚Äôt heard her origin story. In this episode we take a trip back to 2016, to a world that looked much different to today, together with two of Miquela‚Äôs creators ‚Äì Trevor McFedries and Isaac Bratzel ‚Äì cofounder and Chief Design and Innovation Officer of Brud at the time.

We learn what inspired the experiment and what early signs indicated that Miquela was not just a novel idea. In a world where spinning up an influencer, we learn what it took to capture mindshare, the pushback they‚Äôve received, what a ‚Äúscalable influencer‚Äù means, and what they think is to come.

10:15 • 2 months ago

Zaisan

Tokenisation of Real World Assets Explained

Tokenisation is one of the latest web3 trends to emerge. It has taken the world by storm through its relatively simple yet practical use cases in a wide range of industries. In this article, we will explain what it means to tokenise real world assets, the key aspects of tokenising real world assets, the process [‚Ä¶] The post Tokenisation of Real World Assets Explained appeared first on Zaisan.

Tokenisation is one of the latest web3 trends to emerge. It has taken the world by storm through its relatively simple yet practical use cases in a wide range of industries. In this article, we will explain what it means to tokenise real world assets, the key aspects of tokenising real world assets, the process of tokenising a real world asset, and the benefits and disadvantages of tokenising real world assets.

Key takeaways The tokenisation of real world assets is the process of creating a (fractionalised) digital twin of a physical asset that can be held, bought, and traded on a blockchain. The tokenisation process consists of 3 steps, namely pre-tokenisation step, which refers to all the steps that happen in the real, non-digital, world before the asset is tokenised and put on a chain. The tokenisation step refers to putting all relevant data and data pointers on a blockchain and creating the tokens. And lastly, the post-tokenisation step refers to the distribution of the tokens and the management of the physical asset and tokens. There are 5 key aspects of tokenisation that need to be considered during the process of tokenising and securitising real world assets: technology, secondary markets & liquidity, legal & compliance, custody & settlements, and dispute resolution. The benefits of tokenising real world assets are the fractionalisation of assets, greater liquidity, increased transparency, and lower transaction costs. The disadvantages and possible risks of tokenising real world assets are the fragmentation of ownership, regulatory uncertainty, technical complexity, and counterparty risk. The future of tokenisation is uncertain as there are many challenges ahead before tokenisation can become mainstream but with the right people leading the way tokenisation can become the future of asset management, given the great potential of the tokenisation of real world assets.

Note: this article is also available as an eBook in PDF format, so you can download, read, and share it at your convenience.

Let‚Äôs start with what the tokenisation of real world assets actually means!

What is the tokenisation of real world assets?

The tokenisation of real world assets refers to the process of creating a (fractionalised) digital twin of a real world asset that can be traded on a blockchain network. The tokenisation process comes with a variety of benefits. Such are the ability to exchange and own the asset in a more secure and transparent manner. But also things like the provenance of the asset, as well as proofs of labor, and more.

The tokenisation of assets also allows them to be divided into smaller parts, making them available to a wider range of investors. Additionally, these assets can easily be traded on global marketplaces increasing their availability to a wide range of investors even further.

Real world asset tokenisation is not limited to certain types of asset classes either. Instead, tokenisation has the potential to benefit a diverse range of asset classes such as tangible assets like real estate, art, precious metals, and luxury goods, as well as intangible assets such as financial instruments, invoices, and carbon credits.

Fractional ownership of properties, for instance, is possible through the tokenisation of real estate, allowing investors to buy and sell small percentages of high-value properties. Similarly, the tokenisation of art can make art investments more accessible to a broader range of investors by allowing them to buy and sell fractions of high-value pieces.

Lastly, tokenisation can potentially solve some of the challenges linked with traditional ownership structures. Tokenisation enables more transparent and efficient ownership structures that can reduce expenses, fraud, and disputes. Smart contracts can also automate many of the processes associated with asset ownership, including transfers, payments, and maintenance.

How the tokenisation of real world assets works

Now it‚Äôs clear what the tokenisation of real world assets actually means. Let‚Äôs take a look at what the process of tokenising a real world asset looks like.
In short, the process can be described in 3 main steps, namely the pre-tokenisation, tokenisation, and post-tokenisation steps. Let‚Äôs explain this further!

Pre-tokenisation

Pre-tokenisation refers to all the steps that happen in the real, non-digital, world before the asset is tokenised and put on a chain. The main parts of this step depend on the type of asset that is being tokenised. It can generally be divided into formalising the value of the asset, verifying ownership of the asset, and ensuring the right processes are in place in order to take care of the maintenance and management of the physical asset, as well as legal processes in case of liquidations, dispute resolutions, and enforcement.

Tokenisation

Once the pre-tokenisation step has been completed. It is time to make a digital representation of the asset in the form of tokens. The main part of this step is making sure all relevant information about the asset is either put on a blockchain or pointed to from the blockchain and then creating the tokens of the real world asset.

The connection between relevant data in traditional databases and data on the blockchain is facilitated through the use of (decentralised) oracles in order to ensure all relevant information is accurately represented on the blockchain. These oracles collect data from traditional databases and broadcast it to the blockchain. Furthermore, decentralised oracles do the same but do this collectively in order to reach a consensus on the accuracy and validity of the data being broadcasted to the blockchain.

Post-tokenisation

After the previous steps have been completed and the tokenised asset has been created, it‚Äôs time to start distributing/selling the tokenised assets. This is typically done through marketplaces or offerings specialised in these kinds of assets. Part of this step is also the perpetual management of both the physical asset and the tokens based on the rules previously set. For something like an art piece this could include the storage of the piece, maintenance of the piece, insurance of the piece, etc., as well as the management of the tokens, including the management of the information about the token.

Watch it here Key aspects of the tokenisation of real world assets

During the tokenisation process the value chain with its stakeholders remains central. Here are 5 key aspects of tokenisation that need to be considered during the process of tokenising and securitising real world assets which all play a role in the success of the whole process. They can be summarised as follows:

Technology Secondary markets & Liquidity Legal & Compliance Custody & Settlement Dispute resolution

Let‚Äôs take a look at each of these aspects!

1. Technology

One of the first and foremost aspects of the tokenisation process is the technology aspect. This refers to all the technical questions such as which blockchain will be used, what data standards will be used, if the tokens will be fungible or non-fungible, and more.

The type of blockchain that is best suited for tokenising an asset usually depends on the goals one has in mind when tokenising an asset. Different blockchains have different data standards suited for specific purposes and different marketplaces which facilitate the trading of tokens of real world assets. Additionally, the costs of deploying a tokenised asset on a certain blockchain is of importance. Another key component is smart contract support and the preferred programming language of the smart contracts. And lastly, specific communities on a blockchain can also influence if a tokenised asset is likely to succeed in a certain ecosystem.

All of these considerations combined, along with the decision to go for a certain data standard which determines whether you will end up with a fungible or non-fungible token can be a key determining factor of the success of the tokenised asset.

2. Secondary markets & Liquidity

The second aspect to consider during the tokenisation process is the availability of secondary markets and liquidity. This is usually closely related to the choice of blockchain, as most marketplaces tend to support tokens or assets from a single blockchain. Although this is likely to change with a multi-chain future around the corner.

Nevertheless, the availability of trusted and proven marketplaces and a community to facilitate the liquidity of the tokens is essential for the success of a tokenised asset.

3. Legal & Compliance

The third aspect to consider in the tokenisation process is the regulatory and legal side of things which is relevant at all stages of the process, especially for assets that are deemed to be securities or require other regulatory oversight.

The first part of this is regulatory compliance. Tokenising physical assets usually involves regulatory requirements depending on the jurisdiction in which the asset is located. For example, in the United States, securities laws may apply if the tokens represent ownership in the asset and are sold to investors. Compliance with anti-money laundering (AML) and know-your-customer (KYC) regulations are usually also required either when selling the tokens or when registering on a token marketplace.

The process of issuing tokens should also be carried out in compliance with applicable laws and regulations. This includes ensuring that the tokens are not being sold as unregistered securities. And lastly, there may be tax implications when tokenising a real world asset.

4. Custody & Settlements

The fourth aspect to consider in the tokenisation process are any custody and settlement requirements. The tokenisation process basically just creates a digital twin of the asset, but for the asset to actually be tokenised various things ought to be considered. For example, it should be ensured that the ownership of the real world asset is actually in the hands of the token holders. And that the party that tokenises the real world asset holds the deeds and titles to prove the ownership of the asset at the time of tokenisation.

But this is of course not the only relevant point related to this aspect of the tokenisation process. Other things like the management of the physical asset needs to be carefully outlined. This refers to things like loans that need to be repaid before an asset can be released, measurements to prevent (and insure against) things like theft, loss, or damage also need to be agreed upon and be put in place, or arrangements regarding the movement, renovation, etc. of an asset.

These aforementioned considerations mostly refer to the management of the physical asset. But for the tokens, there are also various considerations depending on the jurisdiction. There may be restrictions on the transfer of tokens representing ownership of physical assets. For example, in some cases, the transfer of ownership may require the involvement of a licensed broker or agent.

5. Dispute resolution

The fifth and final aspect of the tokenisation process is dispute resolution. Even with all arrangements and precautions in place there will always be times where there are misunderstandings and disputes. So how does this work with tokenised real world assets?

When it comes to dispute resolution in the context of tokenised physical assets, the process can vary. This depends on the specific platform or protocol being used to facilitate the tokenisation. In most cases, the smart contract of the tokenised asset outlines the exact rules and agreements related to the token (and real world asset), as well as the process for dispute resolution.

However, another approach is to rely on established legal systems and frameworks to resolve disputes. For example, if a dispute arises between parties involved in a tokenised real estate transaction, traditional real estate laws, and courts could be used to resolve the dispute.

Nevertheless, it‚Äôs worth noting that tokenisation of physical assets is a relatively new technology. There may be some legal grey areas and uncertainties when it comes to dispute resolution. As a result, it‚Äôs important for parties involved in tokenised physical asset transactions to seek legal advice and carefully consider the terms and conditions of any smart contracts or agreements before entering into a transaction.

Benefits of tokenisation of real world assets

But what exactly are the benefits of tokenising real world assets? Some of these advantages can be summarised as follows:

Fractionalisation Greater liquidity Increased transparency Lower transaction costs 1. Fractionalisation

Tokenisation allows assets to be divided into smaller portions which means that investors can buy and sell fractions of an asset, rather than having to buy the whole asset. For example, instead of buying an entire real estate property, investors can purchase a percentage of ownership in the property. This opens up investment opportunities to a wider range of investors, including those who may not have enough capital to buy an entire asset.

Another benefit of the fractionalisation is that it allows for more flexible ownership structures which can be better tailored to the investors, in turn increasing the appeal of the investment.

Lastly, the fractionalisation of assets can also be beneficial for community building, in the case of valuable art for example. Instead of having a single owner, it becomes a community-owned asset which can increase both the appeal and value of a physical asset. Who wouldn‚Äôt want to own part of the Mona Lisa?

2. Greater liquidity

Tokenisation makes assets more accessible and tradable on a blockchain, which can increase liquidity. In traditional markets, it can be difficult to find buyers and sellers for certain assets. However, by tokenising an asset and trading it on a blockchain, investors can quickly and easily buy and sell the tokens without needing to go through intermediaries. This can increase the speed and efficiency of transactions, making it easier for investors to enter and exit the market. And unlike traditional asset purchases transactions are instantaneous and seamless.

Furthermore, given that the asset is split up into smaller portions (represented by tokens) the asset becomes an investment opportunity to a wider range of investors, increasing liquidity even further.

It is important to note though that this is not the case for every type of asset depending on the jurisdiction in which the physical asset resides. Token transactions may still be subject to rules and regulations which can make the buying or transfer process equally inefficient as the regular process, and possibly even more cumbersome in some cases.

3. Increased transparency

Tokenisation can make it easier to track ownership and movement of assets, as all transactions are recorded on a blockchain. This increases transparency and reduces the risk of fraudulent activity, as ownership of the asset is easily verifiable. Additionally, since all transactions are recorded on the blockchain, it is easier to audit the history of the asset (and tokens). Thus, this can be important for compliance and regulatory purposes.

This can also be beneficial for tracking the provenance of certain assets, as the digital twin can contain the full history of the physical asset.

4. Lower transaction costs

Generally speaking, tokenisation can reduce the costs associated with buying, selling, and managing assets. By removing the need for intermediaries like brokers and custodians, tokenisation can significantly reduce transaction fees. Additionally, tokenisation has the potential to make it easier to manage assets. All ownership and transaction data is stored on the blockchain, reducing administrative and legal costs associated with traditional asset management.

It is important to mention however that the tokenisation process can also increase costs if the stakeholders want greater trust and transparency before, during, and after the tokenisation process.

Disadvantages of tokenisation of real world assets

As with any novel technology, there are never only advantages. Some of the disadvantages and possible risks of tokenising real world assets can be summed up as follows:

Fragmentation Regulatory uncertainty Technical complexity Counterparty risk 1. Fragmentation

While fractionalisation can be seen as a benefit, it can also lead to the fragmentation of ownership. The more diversified the ownership of an asset becomes, the more difficult it will be to reach consensus on decisions related to the asset which can possibly lead to conflicts between token holders, which consecutively could impact the value of the asset.

2. Regulatory uncertainty

As the use of tokenisation is relatively nascent, there is still regulatory uncertainty surrounding it. This can create challenges for both investors and issuers alike, as they may be unsure about how to comply with regulations, and which regulations apply to tokenisation exactly.

Furthermore, new regulations surrounding tokenisation could also pose new threats and hurdles to the overall tokenisation process.

3. Technical complexity

Tokenisation requires technical knowledge to implement. It can prove to be a barrier for everyday asset owners looking to tokenise their assets. But a steep learning curve is not the only possible barrier. A lack of understanding of all the aspects of the technological side can lead to poorly designed and written smart contracts. In turn, this opens the door to hackers and cyberattacks.

Furthermore, given the technical complexity of using this kind of technology token holders of lower technical proficiency may be more susceptible to falling for new forms of scams and hacks.

4. Counterparty risk

While tokenisation can reduce the need for intermediaries, it can also create new forms of counterparty risk. As is the case with any type of marketplace or exchange, if the tokens are held on that marketplace or exchange, you do not control the funds yourself. If one of these exchanges goes bankrupt or gets hacked, it can become difficult to recover the investments on that marketplace or exchange.

While this can of course be mitigated by taking the tokens out of the platform, history has shown that many people still prefer the convenience of keeping their tokens on an exchange, despite the possible risks. Furthermore, if organisations want to manage their tokenised assets themselves they might require specific roles and functions to manage the relevant wallets which hold the tokens.

Fractional ownership: the future?

The tokenisation of real world assets has clear benefits and opens up many new opportunities. However, on the flip side, there are also many challenges ahead. As with any nascent technology, it remains to be seen whether tokenisation will become the norm for ownership of various types of real world assets or just a small technological sidestep with little impact.

For tokenisation to become the norm, pioneers will need to pave the way for others. There will need to be major developments in terms of technology, marketplaces, regulations, and more before tokenisation can become mainstream. Nonetheless, with the clear benefits in mind and the constantly growing interest in web3 technologies , the future seems bright for tokenisation.

To help companies navigate through the tokenisation process, Zaisan offers end-to-end tokenisation services. Zaisan allows you to focus on the things you do best, while Zaisan takes care of the rest.

The post Tokenisation of Real World Assets Explained appeared first on Zaisan.

09:00 • 2 months ago

Verida

Revolutionizing Web3 Storage: A Deep Dive into IPFS and Verida DbStore

In today‚Äôs digital world, data storage is a crucial component for all applications, regardless of their scope or complexity. While traditional Web2 offers a wealth of storage options tailored to various use cases, such as SQL, NoSQL, Filestorage, S3, and FTP, the transition to Web3 demands a similar expansion of storage infrastructure to accommodate its unique requirements. IPFS has emerged as th

In today‚Äôs digital world, data storage is a crucial component for all applications, regardless of their scope or complexity. While traditional Web2 offers a wealth of storage options tailored to various use cases, such as SQL, NoSQL, Filestorage, S3, and FTP, the transition to Web3 demands a similar expansion of storage infrastructure to accommodate its unique requirements.

IPFS has emerged as the de-facto standard for storing data in Web3, with its decentralized file storage protocol being ideal for images, videos, and static content. However, IPFS was never designed to handle personal data, and thus, a more suitable solution is necessary.

Enter Verida DbStore, the first ‚Äúself-sovereign‚Äù database infrastructure for Web3, which promises to revolutionize how data is managed by offering users guaranteed ownership, the speed and performance of traditional databases, and the ability to permanently delete their data. As a new decentralized infrastructure and architecture, Verida DbStore is specifically designed for rapid access to highly changing, structured personal data with encryption as a fundamental aspect of the protocol.

Let‚Äôs delve into the intricacies of IPFS and Verida DbStore, comparing their architecture, security, performance, storage types, and suitability for handling personally identifiable information (PII).

At a glance: IPFS vs Verida DbStore Architecture

IPFS consists of a peer-to-peer (P2P) network of block storage nodes, where each node is responsible for data identified by its unique hash. Users can retrieve data from any node, which collaborates with other nodes to locate and return the requested information.

IPFS consists of a peer-to-peer (P2P) network of block storage nodes

On the other hand, Verida is a P2P network of database storage nodes, each responsible for a user-specific queryable database. Data on the network is identified by the owner and database name. To retrieve data, users look up the database storage nodes associated with a user and request the data from one or more nodes. Data is replicated across multiple nodes based on geographical and user preferences.

With Verida, a user can use their private key to sign, encrypt and access their data Type of storage

IPFS stores unstructured blobs of data such as images, videos or PDFs.

Verida stores structured data in a document database that can be queried, indexed and replicated.

Security

IPFS lacks native authentication or encryption, making all stored data publicly accessible without permissions or security restrictions, akin to a globally distributed hard drive with universal read access.

In contrast, Verida incorporates end-to-end encryption as a fundamental aspect of its protocol. All data requires authorization for access and a decryption key, ensuring security on par with traditional database infrastructure. Verida also offers flexible permission configuration for each user database, allowing control over read, write, update, and delete permissions.

Performance

IPFS, inspired by torrenting technology, uses distributed hash tables to find content across nodes. While this allows for fast read responses when data is cached locally, it leads to significant latency in discovering new data, resulting in unpredictable and slow response times. This latency issue makes IPFS unsuitable for dynamically changing data without additional protocols.

Real world data from Cloudflare showing an average response time of 44.4 seconds for newly created content on IPFS.

In contrast, Verida is designed for sub-second reads and writes. Although there‚Äôs some initial overhead in discovering a user‚Äôs database, once connected, data transfer occurs via a P2P socket connection. This makes Verida ideal for applications requiring ‚Äúweb2-like‚Äù performance, where interactions are primarily ‚Äúapp-to-user‚Äù or ‚Äúuser-to-user.‚Äù

Suitable for PII

Personally Identifiable Information (PII) includes sensitive data like health records, names, addresses, and financial records that are legally protected in most countries. Regulations dictate the storage, transfer, and user rights concerning PII.

IPFS, a globally decentralized network, is unsuitable for storing PII because it offers no control over data storage or replication, nor guarantees data deletion, which is necessary for compliance with the ‚Äúright to be forgotten‚Äù in many jurisdictions.

Verida DbStore, also a globally decentralized network, allows users to control where their data is stored. By default, the Verida Wallet selects storage nodes in the user‚Äôs country or region, ensuring regulatory compliance. Users can change these nodes or host their own for greater self-sovereignty. They can also delete their data from storage nodes, delete their identity and data entirely, and exercise their ‚Äúright to be forgotten.‚Äù Verida combines the advantages of decentralization with regulatory compliance.

The Verida Client SDK is designed to empower user‚Äôs to control where their data is stored. IPFS as a base layer

Numerous projects are developing decentralized database infrastructure for Web3 using IPFS, including Textile, Ceramic, and Web5. At first glance, this approach may appear logical, as IPFS serves as the filesystem for Web3 and could potentially be transformed into a queryable database. However, this strategy proves to be impractical.

This approach is similar to constructing a permissioned, encrypted MySQL on a public S3 bucket. This would be slow and vulnerable to security threats, making it an undesirable option. While some projects incorporate an encryption layer over IPFS, the eventual breaking of current encryption would leave the data exposed, as it is both public and permanently accessible. In contrast, Verida safeguards encrypted data through authentication and authorization layers, adhering to industry best practices for protecting sensitive information.

To address these issues, some projects introduce additional server-side infrastructure on top of IPFS, forming new ‚Äústorage networks.‚Äù However, if extra infrastructure is necessary, it would be more efficient to build on a foundation designed as a database from the outset, rather than relying on an ill-suited base technology like IPFS.

It is essential to note that IPFS is suitable for various use cases, such as storing immutable public records, NFT images or videos, or whitepaper PDFs. However, it is not an ideal choice for personal data storage, which necessitates a more fitting alternative.

Verida‚Äôs approach

At Verida, we‚Äôve adopted a groundbreaking approach by creating nodes that are not based on IPFS, but rather on well-established database technology that supports authorization, permissions, and decentralized identity standards. This innovative strategy combines the best of both worlds: the reliability of battle-tested, industry-leading database technology and seamless integration with emerging decentralized identity standards through our provided SDKs and server components.

In a world where users can own their personal data, it‚Äôs critical to provide a mechanism to share encrypted data with third parties. The Verida protocol leverages encrypted data replication which is facilitated by peer-to-peer database synchronization at the protocol level.

This standards based architecture allows for the addition of various storage engines, making Verida DbStore the first of many decentralized storage solutions expected to emerge over the next decade. This forward-thinking infrastructure ensures that we stay ahead in the evolution of Web3.

We invite you to explore Verida DbStore through the interactive tutorial in our developer documentation and join us on our mission to empower users with self-sovereign identity and data.

Together, we can shape the future of Web3 and unlock its full potential.

Want to learn more? Join #dev-chat in our Discord community Check out the Verida developer docs Get started with Verida Partner with Verida and build with us Subscribe to our YouTube for more tech explainers, demos and more Follow and tag us on Twitter Subscribe to our mailing list and never miss a Verida update

Revolutionizing Web3 Storage: A Deep Dive into IPFS and Verida DbStore was originally published in Verida on Medium, where people are continuing the conversation by highlighting and responding to this story.

00:58 • 2 months ago

Tuesday, 28. March 2023

Horizen - Blog

Empowering the Horizen Community: The Zenvangelist Program and Its Impact

Communities play an important role in any blockchain and crypto projects. Community members became project ambassadors and were the first to spread the word about these new revolutionary technologies. In this article, see how Horizen leverages its community thanks to its ambassador program. Blockchain and crypto projects rely on their communities.  It is due to [‚Ä¶] The post Empowering th

Communities play an important role in any blockchain and crypto projects. Community members became project ambassadors and were the first to spread the word about these new revolutionary technologies. In this article, see how Horizen leverages its community thanks to its ambassador program.

Blockchain and crypto projects rely on their communities. 

It is due to the precursory character of these technologies. They are too avant-garde for the mainstream media and too complicated for the general public. It took communities to be able to take an interest in emerging projects and to promote them more widely.

Take bitcoin, for example. One of its strengths is drawn from its original community, the cypherpunks. These are the best cryptographers in the world who helped the bitcoin technology emerge and have given it credit, as well as shedding light on revolutionary technology.

What is a (crypto) community?

Suppose we have a look at the definition of community. In that case, we find:

a unified body of individuals: such as the people with common interests living in a particular area  a group of people with a common characteristic or interest living together within a larger society a body of persons of common and especially professional interests scattered through a larger society

(source: https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/community) 

Crypto communities were born with people with shared crypto and freedom interests, living on the internet. They are linked by a shared policy (e.g., decentralization, banking freedom, currency sovereignty) but are still part of a larger society. Everybody can join the ownership by owning cryptos! And that‚Äôs the beautiful thing about it. 

Now that we know that the emergence of crypto and blockchain technologies is due to their communities, how do we use this strength by being a blockchain project?

The answer is with Horizen and its Zenvangelists!

The Horizen Ambassador Program

The Zenvangelists are active members form the Horizen community who are dedicated to contributing to and growing with Horizen.

 Zenvangelists are web3 believers from all walks of life who are passionate about Horizen. Anybody can become a Zenvangelist, as long as they are:

A part of the Horizen community. Interested in cryptocurrencies and blockchain technology in general Always willing to help other members of the community Eager to contribute to the growth of the Horizen community Want to be committed to continuous learning and education Be a self-starter (autonomous, self-taught, in short: passionate)

How do we empower our Zenvangelists?

We are always available for guidance and support We hold monthly meetings where they can discuss community matters and share ideas with the Horizen team and leadership Zenvangelists have exclusive early access to new Horizen product and service releases before the public We help Zenvangelists grow their personal network and reach, improve their skill sets, and provide event opportunities to represent Horizen. We reward Zenvangelists for their effort in many ways, including swagkit, ZEN rewards, free event participations etc. Some are Legends!

They are OGs, community, and project backbones or have joined us recently but have shown exceptional activity: let me introduce you to the Legend Zenvangelists.

Let me introduce you to our Zenvangelists: Mahnoor, our daily task moderator, PVM, our party organizer, DeFi-Money-Printer, our livestream host, Paragism, our technical writer and Xavier, our technologies tester and community teacher. 

We didn‚Äôt forget our OGs: Jonghun, Guan, Sidarta, and Psyrax.

Let‚Äôs get to know each of them a little more!

Why Horizen?

Mahnoor: In short, I chose Horizen because of its strong community, its innovative vision, and its potential to make a real difference in the world.

PVM: Mainly because of the privacy focus, constant development, and great potential. The innovating sidechains were giving new tools to developers, with $ZEN powering the future of DeFi, Play2Earn games, DApps, Web3, and NFT projects

DeFi: What first garnered my interest in crypto, as many like to joke about being ‚Äúin it for the tech‚Äù was truly my growing interest in GPU mining. I‚Äôd tried to mine Ethereum at the time and had been failing with graphics drivers and related issues, so I found that ZEC was comparably profitable at the time and was easy to set up and get going.

When I found that Horizen would have the same algorithm and supply of coins, I saw opportunity at being an early supporter. The passion of the team at an early stage and to this day has always been something that stands out to me.

Xavier: Horizen looked like a big project and has since grown even bigger. There are 3 companies, a doxxed team, a news website, a blog, the academy, an open GitHub, the Horizen Early Adopter‚Äôs Program, and the HDE (Horizen Developer Environment). There are tools for the community: Discord, Twitter accounts, and Telegram channels ‚Ä¶ It even has a meme coin^^

There was a lot of work to build the Zendoo protocol, and since it was released, a new era has started, with Tokenmint and EON. I hope many sidechains will be added to the ecosystem in the coming months/years.

Paragism: The strong ethos of privacy attracted me initially. I also found Horizen very dedicated to bringing new innovations with its research-driven culture and strives to push technological boundaries. This blockchain project keeps delivering back-to-back developments with continuous R&D regarding various vital parameters to achieve high scalability and extendibility.

Michael: The project has a clear vision, excellent leadership, a capable team, unique technology, and major industry partners. Horizen ticks all the boxes, and with Horizen EON launching, we will soon see Horizen carve out its market fit.

Jonghun: At the end of 2017, while preparing for my own business, I wanted to learn more about the blockchain area. At that time, I found the ZenCash homepage and sent a direct email to send a proposal saying that I would like to work while learning.

We also asked for consent by presenting an article on zencash‚Äôs forum, which is now unused.

At the same time, I conducted various communication, such as sharing many conversations and Korean market research.

Based on that, I joined the current Horizen, and I strongly agree with the direction we are heading now, the role as a platform, and the cultivation of an ecosystem that focuses on practically necessary privacy such as Data-Privacy.

I first announced the launch of Horizen Korea at ZenCon0, and since then I have made preliminary contact with many partners for Horizen Korea in Korea.

Now that we are almost ready to announce the business outline and official launch, we will soon be able to meet Horizen Korea, which is taking on various challenges as much as the Korean community members expect of Horizen.

Guan: Because the project has a sustainable funding model and cool graphic designs. Horizen is an inclusive ecosystem where everyone is rewarded for their contributions.

For how long have you been in the Horizen community? Share your journey in crypto communities?

Mahnoor: I‚Äôve been actively involved in the crypto ecosystem since 2019, and I‚Äôve been passionate about the potential of blockchain technology to transform the way we live and work. Since then, I‚Äôve been exploring different projects and communities in the space, and I was excited to join the Horizen team in late 2021.

As someone who has always been interested in the intersection of technology and finance, I was drawn to Horizen‚Äôs vision of a decentralized, privacy-focused ecosystem that empowers individuals to control their assets and data. I‚Äôve been impressed by the team‚Äôs commitment to innovation and dedication to building a community-driven platform that can make a difference in people‚Äôs lives.

As a tracker of daily task submissions, I‚Äôve had the opportunity to engage with Horizen users daily and see firsthand their enthusiasm and passion for the project. I‚Äôm honored to be part of such a vibrant and dynamic community, and I‚Äôm excited to see what the future holds for Horizen and the wider crypto ecosystem.

PVM: I joined the Zenvangelists in May 2021. I was expanding my reach into the Cryptoverse and was happy I could join the community. I was enhancing my blockchain knowledge, and Horizen was one of the chains that impressed me.

DeFi: I‚Äôve been involved with Horizen since early 2017 very near the launch of the project when I first heard about it being supported on the first ever exchange for Horizen, Bittrex, which happened to be the first alt-coin exchange I had used in my crypto journey.

Xavier: I don‚Äôt remember when I first heard about Bitcoin, but at the time, I thought it was cooler to search for Alien life running SETI or help research with Folding@home than to mine cryptocurrencies.

I saw all this crash in 2018 and thought the ecosystem had turned to silly speculation.

But, after a while, during the bear market, I started looking into the ecosystem again and saw great people building interesting projects. I bought some cryptos and read a lot of whitepapers.

I started a website. The first tutorials I wrote were about Bitgreen and Zelcash (now Flux) configuration.

In 2020, I started looking into masternodes and Horizen was one of my first ones. A Secure Node was cheap, and the APY was very good before the halving.

I started to dig deeper into Horizen with the public release of Zendoo on the testnet, tested it on a VPS, completed some HDE tasks, and therefore wrote some articles.

Michael: Horizen was one of the first coins I bought when I started my crypto journey in 2017. I wasn‚Äôt active in the community then, but I used to lurk on Telegram. I was always impressed by how accessible the team was, and Rob was always in the chat, answering questions and engaging with the community.  His passion was infectious. During the 2018/19 bear market, I became more involved in the community. I tried to help where I could, such as live streaming the weekly team meetings, amplifying Horizen news through HorizenClips, and doing some end-of-year and zendoo launch community Livestream events.

Jonghun: I learned about Bitcoin from the end of 2015 and started mining with my computer at home. I didn‚Äôt get as much volume as the current Bitcoin whales, but I started to pay more attention to the technology called blockchain rather than profit.

Technically, it came out earlier, but the technology that was almost dead came back to the world through an example of Bitcoin, and since then, as new technologies such as Ethereum‚Äôs smart contracts have been introduced, the blockchain industry has begun to draw attention.

These days, diversity that can be utilized within the blockchain industry, such as NFT, is possible, but in the past, there were many people who took a business approach with a conceptual nature as a simple payment method. In it, I was obsessed with the thought of whether it would be right for someone to look into my wallet address, even though it is a wallet address made up of addresses that are very long and difficult for people to memorize.

From this point of view, even in terms of a simple payment method, we can see the importance of privacy.

Do you have something to say to those who want to join the Zenvangelist program or any crypto community?

Mahnoor: For those interested in joining the Zenvangelist program or any other crypto community, I would say: go for it! Being part of a community is a great way to learn, grow, and contribute to a larger cause. It‚Äôs an opportunity to meet like-minded individuals, share your knowledge and experience, and make a difference.

My advice would be to start by getting involved in the community in whatever way feels most comfortable to you. This could mean joining a Discord group, participating in social media discussions, attending meetups or events, or contributing to open-source projects. Whatever you choose, be sure to stay engaged, be respectful, and be open-minded. Everyone in the community is there to learn and grow; working together can achieve great things.

Finally, don‚Äôt be afraid to take on leadership roles and responsibilities within the community. Whether becoming a Zenvangelist, organizing an event, or contributing to a project, stepping up and taking action is the best way to make a real impact and show dedication to the cause. So, if you‚Äôre passionate about crypto and blockchain, I encourage you to get involved and join a community today.

PVM: The Zenvangelist Program, like the majority of crypto communities, empowers the users. You bring your skills, work with others, and learn. Being part of a strong, vibrant, and fun community will bring more knowledge than many courses.

DeFi: For any community members whether new or old my greatest advice to give would be to never underestimate the impact you may have on the communities and projects you are involved in, and in many cases opportunities will arise and those passionate community members certainly stand out of the crowd (and if not make sure you let yourself be heard in a constructive manner) a little effort goes a long way when we all work together to build something greater than one team or project can build alone.

Paragism: Horizen community is rich in resources. It will enable you to share personal relatedness and support the perpetual growth of the ecosystem. The sense of togetherness is profound and enjoyable here.

Xavier: Joining a crypto community is still the best way to learn about the ecosystem and a project.

The more you speak with people, meet others, and share what you know, the more your knowledge and comprehension grow. That‚Äôs a win-win. You become better and help others understand our ecosystem.

Michael: I say jump in! The Zenvangelist program is great because you can tailor it to suit your own unique talents! It is also a great way for you to get to know the team and community better, and it can help open lots of doors if you are pursuing a career in crypto.

Jonghun: Sure! In the Korean community, there are many valuable members who play many roles. For example, AstarZen is directly producing PFP NFTs for node operators in our Korean community. Needless to say, Ken is also the spiritual pillar of our Korean community.

Guan: We are an honest and lovely community with many interesting and smart people! Come on and join us, You won‚Äôt regret it!

How does it feel to be named Legend Zenvangelist?

Mahnoor: Being recognized as a Legend Zenvangelist within the Horizen community is amazing. Being acknowledged for my contributions and dedication is an honor.

I believe it helps promote the project, impart my wisdom and experience, and assist in adopting and engaging new users.

However, having the title of Legend Zenvangelist carries more obligations than just a title. It entails continuing to be involved and active in the community, sharing my knowledge and suggestions, and assisting in determining the project‚Äôs direction. It entails setting an example for others and motivating them to get involved and change the world.

Overall, being recognized as a Legend Zenvangelist is humbling, and it inspires me to keep putting in the effort and helping the Horizen community. I‚Äôm happy to be a part of this thriving ecosystem and eager to see what we can accomplish together.

PVM: I feel proud to be named a Legend Zenvangelist but still humble. It‚Äôs a title that makes me feel appreciated and the reason to keep working as hard as I did until now. Now I have to lead by example and maintain high standards

DeFi: It‚Äôs an honor to be recognized as Legend Zenvagelist, and my pleasure to see where the Horizen Ecosystem has come from, to where it is now, and being a part of where it is going. I truly believe the greater market is largely unaware of the constant building going on throughout the years and could be near the precipice of true recognition as a DeFi, Smart Contract platform ‚Äì being secured by the largest node network and hybrid Proof of Work network structure under the hood.

Paragism: It is a matter of pride. Horizen community has empowered me to bring positive changes. I am grateful that my involvement and work have been recognised.

Xavier: That‚Äôs a funny bonus, but honestly, being called a legend wasn‚Äôt part of the plan when I joined the Zenvangeslists^^

Michael:  I feel a little undeserving because I have been pretty quiet in the community lately as I have been busy launching a new business in Seoul. But Horizen is definitely my favourite project!

Jonghun: I am delighted to hear that I have been selected among the valued Zenvangelists for more diverse endeavors. I am happy that I will work harder in the future with Horizen Korea as my new starting point, but I accept it with a heavy heart.

Guan: I feel so honored to be a Legend Zenvangelist, spreading Horizen is a significant thing in such a very early stage!  I also meet a lot of super cool ZEN-frens from all over the world. It‚Äôs a fantastic journey in my life!

Q: Mahnoor, thank you so much for being here every day for the community. You were even here during your maternity leave to help the fellowship. Where do you find this constant energy to be present in the community?

A: I believe that the crypto and blockchain space has the potential to revolutionize the way we think about money, data, and identity, and I‚Äôm committed to doing my part to help bring about that change. Whether it‚Äôs through tracking daily task submissions, answering questions in Discord groups, or participating in social media discussions, I always try to be available and responsive to community members.

Of course, there are times when it can be challenging to balance community involvement with other responsibilities, such as family or work. But ultimately, I believe that being present for the community is an important part of my role, and I‚Äôm grateful for the opportunity to contribute in any way I can.

Overall, my energy and enthusiasm for the Horizen community comes from my belief in its potential and my passion for the work that we‚Äôre doing. I‚Äôm honored to be a part of this dynamic and innovative ecosystem, and I look forward to continuing to contribute in any way I can.

Q: PVM, you are our event Zenvangelist and an excellent writer. So tell us, what is the best: hosting or participating in the party?

A: Hosting parties and events is fun, and taking part is even better. My friends tell me to make ‚ÄúPVM Entertainment and Leisure‚Äù a real thing, as the events I create are always top of the crop!

This is what I love to do ‚Ä¶ to create events that suit every crypto user, from NFT lovers to Crypt edges. I constantly think about new party activities and themes and ways to reward the participants with memories and good vibes‚Äù

Q: DeFi, you are the new Horizen community voice. You have great skills in hosting and green screen management. What came first, the desire to play with editing software or to talk about the Horizen project entertainingly?

A: AI would say my desire in content, editing, and feeling though I have an above average understanding of many concepts that others may benefit from all to tie in together, but to answer which came first, it was the tinkering around while bringing some creativity to the mix ‚Äì I‚Äôd been doing so since the Windows XP era on Windows Movie Maker‚Ä¶ Although the quality and effort was poor at best, I always try to make incremental improvements over time (even if it means two steps forwards, one step back at times).

Q: Paragism, what is different in the Horizen community?

A: The Horizen community gives a sense of belonging. All ideas are welcomed and we get to see plenty of expressions. The community members also get to learn new things and hone their skills.

Q: Xavier, you are the always-willing-to-try-tech-things-guy among the Zenvangelists. You make great tutorials and create love, hug, and cakes in our tokenization platform and EVM. Where does this genuine willingness to share come from?

A: I love tech. I love to learn new technologies. I started coding at 7 and never stopped learning different flavors of basic (Turbo) pascal, c, c++, java, SQL, HTML, javascript, php, tcl, ‚Ä¶ and systems administration.

I‚Äôve been sharing my knowledge since 98, I think. It was one of my end of studies projects to write a website generator in java (v1.0.2) and use it to generate a website. The website was called Alaide (that means‚Äúhelp needed‚Äù in French). It was a collection of tutorials about HTML 3.2, CGI programming, and java.

I then wrote articles for the French Linux magazine for several years, mainly about Linux development.

I spent a lot of time browsing the apache forums and community websites like ‚Äúl√©a Linux‚Äù or ‚Äúle site du z√©ro.‚Äù

Nowadays, I work as a freelance sysadmin and developer and help my customers understand and face their tech problems. I‚Äôm still writing tutorials, helping people on Twitter and Discord, testing things, and helping people in their crypto journey.

Q: Jonghun, you‚Äôre more than the Korean community backbone; you made it to the Horizen team! What made you stay at Horizen through the years?

A: I have had various experiences within the blockchain industry.

I helped launch a global exchange in Korea and played the role of COO, and I am advising on various projects.

Unlike many projects, Horizen always develops by clarifying the vision set in the beginning, responding to the market, and knowing how to adapt.

From a currency with a simple privacy function, now as a platform, we are expanding the ecosystem for various projects. Of course, we are preparing to support the use of the Privacy function where it is actually needed, rather than abandoning it.

In the Korean community, not only me but Ken and so many people are moving together.

Maybe not just community members, but each of them speaks a lot about Horizen‚Äôs development direction in a really logical and passionate way.

There was also strong support from the community about removing the shield pool from the main chain this time. When voting on this, members of the Korean community debated day and night.

In addition to my vision for Horizen, Horizen, with such a passionate community, will keep everyone in the future.

Q: Guan, You are an OG who did much for the Horizen community. What made you stay through the years?

A: The team always knows how to push things forward. the project‚Äôs core cross-chain protocol Zendoo solves scalability that can massively help many web2 businesses into web3.

Horizen inspired artwork from Zenvangelist Sidarta0

‚ÄúI love the sleeping astronaut. A lot. But also Topsy Turvy, one of the first artworks that got people from Horizen further interested in letting me have art on their products. I still have the original; it blows my mind that no one has ever bought it. I love the colors and the weird randomness. It was created in the flow. One of my favorites. Because I still remember the process. It was a fun piece to do. And also very hard to do again.‚Äù

Last but not least, special thanks to Psyrax, JC, our Legend Zenvangelist SupportMan, who is always available to assist the community with any node/mining-related questions. You‚Äôre the backbone of our Discord server, essential to the community. So, thank you!

Do you want to join the Horizen Ambassador Program and become a Zenvangelists? Visit this page to apply.

How to get involved without being a Zenvangelist?

Become a #ZenFren and participate in the #daily-tasks channel on Discord to be rewarded for being active in the community.

Join the Horizen Early Adopter Program to test new products before public releases

The HCC‚Äôs goal is to bring more decentralization into the Horizen project.

ZenIPs are meant to push improvement proposals to the greater Horizen ecosystem.

Zcash

ECC Transparency Report for Q3 2022

Why release a transparency report? Electric Coin Co. is committed to openness and transparency ‚Äî as we help evolve and [‚Ä¶] The post ECC Transparency Report for Q3 2022 appeared first on Electric Coin Company.
Why release a transparency report?

Electric Coin Co. is committed to openness and transparency ‚Äî as we help evolve and support the Zcash digital currency, and in support of our mission to empower people with economic freedom. This transparency report details company income, expenses, and use of funds during Q3 2022.

Key takeaways

Bootstrap received coins at a value below the ECC operating-expense level for Q3 2022. During this time, Bootstrap received coins at an average of $461,000 a month (at the Q3 average ZEC price, $60, for each of the three months‚Äô distribution dates), and Bootstrap and ECC incurred average monthly expenses of approximately $766,000.  At the end of Q3 2022, Bootstrap and ECC collectively held approximately $3.0M in USD and approximately 116.9K ZEC.  As of March 16, 2023, the company held approximately $1.3M in USD and approximately 110K ZEC. 

Read the full report.

The post ECC Transparency Report for Q3 2022 appeared first on Electric Coin Company.

18:29 • 2 months ago

Zcash Foundation

Zebra as a package in the Arch User Repository

Marek Bielik introduces the new Zebra package for Arch Linux.
by Marek Bielik

We could start this post by saying that our motivation to create a Zebra package for Arch Linux was that Arch enjoys the highest average rating of any Linux distribution on DistroWatch. However, the truth is that one of our engineers uses Arch (btw.), and he thought it would be handy to have Zebra packaged.

Packages in the official Arch repositories contain compiled binaries signed by their maintainers. The Arch developers maintain essential packages, and so-called trusted users maintain the rest. In addition to the official repositories, the Arch User Repository (AUR) lets anyone from the Arch community share their own package. The difference is that AUR packages do not contain binaries but a script that pulls, builds, and installs the software for the user. Arch users are encouraged to inspect the script‚Äôs content before executing it.

Zebra is currently packaged in the AUR. The package prepares dependencies, pulls Zebra‚Äôs source code from GitHub, and builds and installs the same binary as the official Docker image.

AUR users can vote for a package to increase its popularity, and trusted users can adopt popular packages and promote them to the official repositories. As the ArchWiki says, ‚Äúa good number of new packages that enter the official repositories start in the AUR‚Äù. The original zcashd node already has an official package, and Zebra will hopefully follow. So if you are, by the way, using Arch, feel free to install the zebrad package and let us know how it went on our Discord, or on the Zcash Community Forums.

164 - The FBI Agent Who Took Down the Silk Road with Chris Tarbell

Chris Tarbell is a former FBI Agent specializing in cyber investigations. While at the FBI, Chris led some of the most high-profile cybercrime investigations in the world, including the arrest of members of the hacker group LulzSec, as well as the founder of the Silk Road, Ross Ulbricht, which resulted in the largest seizure of bitcoins to date. ------ ‚ú® DEBRIEF | Unpacking the episode: 

Chris Tarbell is a former FBI Agent specializing in cyber investigations. While at the FBI, Chris led some of the most high-profile cybercrime investigations in the world, including the arrest of members of the hacker group LulzSec, as well as the founder of the Silk Road, Ross Ulbricht, which resulted in the largest seizure of bitcoins to date.

------ ‚ú® DEBRIEF | Unpacking the episode:  https://www.bankless.com/debrief-the-fbi-agent-who-took-down-the-silk-road    ------ ‚ú® COLLECTIBLES | Collect this episode:  https://collectibles.bankless.com/mint 

------ Rarely do we have the opportunity to pick the brain of a cybercop, but this was our opportunity to see through the eyes of the FBI agent who took down the Silk Road in the largest crypto seizure ever recorded.

In today‚Äôs episode, Chris shares the story of crypto, Ross Ulbricht, and the Silk Road as told by the FBI agent who took it down. We also dig into the eternal cat-and-mouse game between Cybercriminals and Cyberpolice, how to protect yourself from people who want to take your crypto, and if the FBI wants your private keys, how they get them.

There are bank runs and also rumors of more bank runs on the horizon. This is our third episode in a series of conversations. To get the full debate you‚Äôll need to listen to the last two episodes with Balaji Srini

There are bank runs and also rumors of more bank runs on the horizon. One side says, ‚Äúthe banks are insolvent, get to the lifeboats.‚Äù Another side says, ‚Äúthe banks are going to be fine‚Ä¶we‚Äôre sick and tired of doomers pulling the fire alarm.‚Äù Who‚Äôs right?

This is our third episode in a series of conversations. To get the full debate you‚Äôll need to listen to the last two episodes with Balaji Srinivasan and Arthur Hayes.

In this episode, we‚Äôre speaking with Ben Hunt who lays out the counterpoint details on why banks are going to be fine. He believes Balaji and Arthur are dangerously wrong. Tune in to hear why!
